His work is characterized by muscular figures, dramatic gestures and bold use of perspective.

Studied under Pietro Perugino, whose influence is visible in his early works such as The Marriage of the Virgin.

title: Pope Julius II
content:
Pope Julius II
Wikipedia
Born: December 5, 1443, Albisola Superiore
Died: February 21, 1513, Rome
Born Giuliano della Rovere, he was Pope from 1503 to 1513. Known as the "Warrior Pope" or "Fearsome Pope," he dominated the High Renaissance in Rome. He commissioned Michelangelo to paint the Sistine Chapel ceiling and Raphael to decorate the Vatican stanze. He also initiated the reconstruction of St. Peter's Basilica under Bramante.
Patronage
Julius II was the most important patron of the High Renaissance, commissioning major works from Michelangelo, Raphael, and Bramante.

Pietro Perugino
Wikipedia
Born: c. 1446-1452, Città della Pieve, Umbria
Died: 1523, Fontignano (plague)
Source: my-study, self-research
Italian Renaissance painter of the Umbrian school who developed some of the qualities that found classic expression in the High Renaissance. Trained under Piero della Francesca and Andrea Verrocchio alongside Leonardo da Vinci. Called to Rome by Sixtus IV to paint frescoes in the Sistine Chapel. Leading painter of the Perugian School. Known for the breadth and distance of his spatial backgrounds. Raphael became his most famous pupil, and Perugino's use of space and perspective influenced many Renaissance artists.

Wikipedia
Born: March 6, 1475, Caprese Michelangelo
Died: February 18, 1564, Rome
Italian sculptor, painter, architect, and poet of the High Renaissance. Considered one of the greatest artists of all time. Unlike Leonardo who was skeptical and apolitical, Michelangelo was a believer and loyal Florentine. Where Leonardo looked on the world with detachment, Michelangelo was obsessed by guilt. Spare, taciturn, and irascible, yet consumed with a deep love for others that only in his old age was requited by the adoring reverence of his pupils.
Worked in Ghirlandaio's study at age 13, and was invited into the house of Lorenzo the Magnificent a year later. Scorned landscape, focusing on the human figure.

Active: 12th–13th century, Rome
Source: self-research
A Roman family of seven members across four generations who were skilled architects, sculptors, and workers in decorative geometric mosaic. They specialized in a technique of opus sectile formed of elaborate inlays of small triangles and rectangles of colored stones and glass mosaics set into stone matrices. Their name is commemorated in the genre of "Cosmatesque" work. Initial inspiration for the technique was Byzantine, transmitted through Ravenna and Sicily, while some of the minutely-figured tiling patterns are Islamic in origin. Their work adorns many Roman churches including Santa Maria in Cosmedin, where the pavement, schola cantorum, pulpit, paschal candlestick, altar canopy, and episcopal throne all bear their distinctive style.

Biblical Context
Assumption of Mary - Mary, mother of Jesus, assumed bodily into Heaven.
Description
Also known as the Assumption of the Virgin, this glittering altarpiece features a three-layered composition with God the Father at the top surrounded by cherubs and angels, the Virgin Mary ascending in the middle, and saints below. One of Perugino's major works.

title: Two Venetian Ladies
subtitle: Vittore Carpaccio · c. 1490-1495 · Oil on panel
content:
Two Venetian Ladies
Wikipedia
Artist: Vittore Carpaccio
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1490-1495
Source: self-research
Description
A famous painting showing two unknown Venetian ladies on a terrace with dogs, birds, and various symbolic objects. Believed to be a quarter of the original work; the top portion, called Hunting on the Lagoon, is now in the Getty Museum. Once thought to depict courtesans, the work is now believed to show two patrician women awaiting the return of their husbands from a hunting expedition.

title: Trophy Reliefs
subtitle: c. 145 CE · Marble relief
content:
Trophy Reliefs
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors
Location: Temple of Hadrian, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. 145 CE
Source: self-research
Description
Relief panels depicting captured arms, armor, and weapons, placed between the province personifications on the temple podium. These trophies symbolize Roman military might and include shields, axes, spears, armor, lances, flags, and a Dacian draco (dragon standard). Three trophy reliefs are displayed in the Capitoline Museums.

title: Trompe-l'œil Dome
subtitle: Andrea Pozzo · 1685 (original, destroyed; reproduced 1823 by Francesco Manno) · Painting on canvas
content:
Trompe-l'œil Dome
Artist: Andrea Pozzo
Location: Sant'Ignazio, Rome
Medium: Painting on canvas
Date: 1685 (original, destroyed; reproduced 1823 by Francesco Manno)
Source: self-research
Description
A flat circular canvas painted to create the illusion of a cupola, since the planned dome was never built due to disputes with the Ludovisi donors. Using masterful perspective, Pozzo created the appearance of a coffered dome when viewed from the correct vantage point in the nave. The original was destroyed by fire and faithfully reproduced in 1823.

title: Triumphal Arch Mosaics
subtitle: c. 432–440 · Mosaic
content:
Triumphal Arch Mosaics
Artist: Unknown
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Mosaic
Date: c. 432–440
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Annunciation - Angel Gabriel announces to Mary she will bear Jesus.
Adoration of the Magi - Wise men visit the infant Jesus.
Presentation in the Temple - Jesus presented to Simeon.
Description
Mosaics on the triumphal arch depicting scenes from the infancy of Christ, including the Annunciation, the Adoration of the Magi, the Massacre of the Innocents, and the Presentation in the Temple. Mary is depicted dressed as a Roman empress, reflecting the Council of Ephesus (431) declaration of Mary as Theotokos (God-bearer). Among the oldest monumental representations of the Virgin Mary in Christian art.

title: Triumph of Venice
subtitle: Palma il Giovane · 1582 · Oil on canvas (ceiling)
content:
Triumph of Venice
Artist: Palma il Giovane
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas (ceiling)
Date: 1582
Source: self-research
Description
A ceiling painting in the Chamber of the Great Council showing Venice crowned by Victory. Part of the decorative program celebrating Venice's glory, executed after the devastating fire of 1577.

title: Tritons with Hippocamps
subtitle: Pietro Bracci · 1761-1762 · Marble sculpture
content:
Tritons with Hippocamps
Artist: Pietro Bracci
Location: Trevi Fountain, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: 1761-1762
Source: self-research
Description
Two tritons guide Oceanus's shell chariot, each controlling a hippocamp (sea horse). One triton blows a conch shell to announce the god's approach, while the other struggles to tame a wild hippocamp. The contrast between the calm and agitated horses symbolizes the moods of the sea.

title: Trinity
subtitle: Masaccio · c. 1427 · Fresco
content:
Trinity
Wikipedia)
Artist: Masaccio
Location: Santa Maria Novella, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 1427
Biblical Context
Holy Trinity - The Christian doctrine of the three persons of God: the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. The fresco depicts Christ crucified, supported by God the Father, with the Holy Spirit (as a dove) between them.
Description
A revolutionary work demonstrating Brunelleschi's principles of linear perspective. One of the first monumental Renaissance paintings to utilize linear perspective. The donors are shown kneeling on either side of the holy scene.

title: Treasury of St Mark's Basilica
subtitle: Various (6th-14th century) · Metalwork, enamels, reliquaries
content:
Treasury of St Mark's Basilica
Wikipedia
Artist: Various Byzantine craftsmen
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Metalwork, enamels, reliquaries
Date: Various (6th-14th century)
Source: self-research
Description
The single best collection of Byzantine metalwork and enamels that survives, many items looted during the Fourth Crusade of 1204. Contains sacred objects including the Votive Crown of Leo VI, chalices, patens, and reliquaries holding fragments purportedly of the True Cross and other sacred relics.

title: Transfiguration
subtitle: Raphael · 1516-1520 · Oil on panel
content:
Transfiguration
Wikipedia)
Artist: Raphael
Location: Vatican Museums, Vatican
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: 1516-1520
Biblical Context
Transfiguration - Jesus is transfigured on a mountain and speaks with Moses and Elijah, witnessed by Peter, James, and John.
Description
Raphael's last painting, left unfinished at his death in 1520 and completed by his workshop. The upper half shows the Transfiguration of Christ on Mount Tabor, while the lower half depicts the Apostles' failed attempt to heal a possessed boy. The painting was displayed at Raphael's funeral and is considered one of his greatest works.

title: Transfiguration of Christ
subtitle: Giovanni Bellini · c. 1480 · Oil on panel
content:
Transfiguration of Christ
Artist: Giovanni Bellini
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1480
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Transfiguration - Jesus revealed in glory upon a mountain, accompanied by Moses and Elijah.
Description
Likely originally from San Salvatore or San Giobbe church. One of several works in the museum representing Giovanni Bellini's mature period.

title: Tornabuoni Chapel Frescoes
subtitle: Domenico Ghirlandaio · 1485–1490 · Fresco and stained glass
content:
Tornabuoni Chapel Frescoes
Wikipedia
Artist: Domenico Ghirlandaio
Location: Santa Maria Novella, Florence
Medium: Fresco and stained glass
Date: 1485–1490
Description
Series of frescoes and stained glass in the Tornabuoni Chapel. This was a work of Ghirlandaio's whole shop, including a 13-year-old apprentice named Michelangelo.

title: Tomb of the Scipios
subtitle: Early 3rd century BC - 1st century AD
content:
Tomb of the Scipios
Wikipedia
Location: Via Appia Antica, Rome
Type: Hypogeum / Family Tomb
Date: Early 3rd century BC - 1st century AD
Source: self-research
Description
The common tomb (hypogaeum Scipionum) of the patrician Scipio family during the Roman Republic. This underground burial chamber served the family for interments over several centuries before being abandoned and lost, only to be rediscovered in later times.

title: Tomb of the Haterii
subtitle: c. AD 100-120 · Marble relief
content:
Tomb of the Haterii
Wikipedia
Location: Vatican Museums (originally Via Labicana, Rome)
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. AD 100-120
Type: Funerary monument
Source: self-research
Description
An ancient Roman funerary monument discovered in 1848 along the Via Labicana. Its reliefs provide valuable documentation of the Colosseum's original decorated appearance, showing the amphitheater with its numerous statues in place. The reliefs are now in the Vatican Museums.

title: Tomb of Pope Sixtus IV
subtitle: Antonio del Pollaiuolo · 1484–1493 · Bronze
content:
Tomb of Pope Sixtus IV
Artist: Antonio del Pollaiuolo
Location: St. Peter's Basilica, Vatican City
Medium: Bronze
Date: 1484–1493
Description
Monumental bronze tomb for Pope Sixtus IV, now in the Treasury of St. Peter's Basilica.

title: Tomb of Lorenzo de' Medici, Duke of Urbino
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1524-1534 · Marble
content:
Tomb of Lorenzo de' Medici, Duke of Urbino
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Basilica of San Lorenzo, Florence (Medici Chapels)
Medium: Marble
Date: 1524-1534
Source: self-research
Description
A monumental tomb featuring a contemplative seated figure of Lorenzo de' Medici, Duke of Urbino, known as "Il Pensieroso" (The Thinker) for his meditative pose with his chin resting on his hand. The allegorical figures of Dawn and Dusk recline on the sarcophagus below.
Dawn is represented as a female figure awakening, her expression suggesting melancholy at the new day. Dusk is a weary male figure, also with an expression of profound sadness. Together with the companion tomb of Giuliano, the ensemble represents Michelangelo's meditation on time, death, and eternity.

title: Tomb of Giuliano de' Medici, Duke of Nemours
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1526-1534 · Marble
content:
Tomb of Giuliano de' Medici, Duke of Nemours
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Basilica of San Lorenzo, Florence (Medici Chapels)
Medium: Marble
Date: 1526-1534
Source: self-research
Description
A monumental tomb featuring an idealized seated portrait of Giuliano de' Medici, Duke of Nemours, with the allegorical figures of Night and Day reclining on the sarcophagus below. The 1.68m-tall marble sculpture forms part of the decorative scheme of the Medici Chapel in San Lorenzo.
Night is represented as a sleeping female figure with symbols of sleep (owl, poppies, mask), while Day is a muscular male figure turning away, his face left unfinished. According to Michelangelo's disciple Ascanio Condivi, the sculptures "signify Day and Night and, in conjunction, Time which devours all things."

title: Tomb of Carlo Marsuppini
subtitle: Desiderio da Settignano · 1453–1455 · Marble
content:
Tomb of Carlo Marsuppini
Artist: Desiderio da Settignano
Location: Santa Croce, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: 1453–1455
Description
Monument tomb created by the stonecutter Desiderio da Settignano for the humanist scholar and Chancellor of Florence Carlo Marsuppini.

title: Tomb of Caecilia Metella
subtitle: c. 30-10 BC
content:
Tomb of Caecilia Metella
Wikipedia
Location: Via Appia Antica, Rome
Type: Mausoleum
Date: c. 30-10 BC
Source: self-research
Description
A cylindrical mausoleum at the three-mile marker of the Via Appia, built to honor Caecilia Metella, daughter of Quintus Caecilius Metellus Creticus (a consul in 69 BC) and wife of Marcus Licinius Crassus, son of the famous triumvir. The castle-like structure dominates the surrounding landscape and is one of the best-preserved monuments along the ancient road.

title: Tomb of Antonio Canova
subtitle: Antonio Canova · 1827 · Marble
content:
Tomb of Antonio Canova
Artist: Antonio Canova (design) and students
Location: Basilica di Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari, Venice
Medium: Marble
Date: 1827
Source: self-research
Description
A pyramidal monument originally designed by Canova as a tomb for Titian. After Canova's death, his students used the design to create his own memorial. His heart is interred here; his body is in Possagno.

title: The Tempest
subtitle: Giorgione · 1506-1508 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Tempest
Wikipedia)
Artist: Giorgione
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1506-1508
Source: self-research
Description
A mysterious Renaissance painting originally commissioned by Venetian noble Gabriele Vendramin. Depicts a soldier and a nursing woman in a lush landscape with a city threatened by a storm. Despite considerable scholarly discussion, the meaning remains elusive. Considered by some the first true landscape in Western art.

title: The Forge of Vulcan
subtitle: Tintoretto · c. 1578 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Forge of Vulcan
Artist: Tintoretto
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1578
Source: self-research
Description
Part of the four mythological paintings in the Sala dell'Anticollegio. Depicts the god Vulcan at his forge, symbolizing industry and craftsmanship. One of the allegories of the virtues of Venice's good government.

title: Temple of Vesta
subtitle: 7th century BC (rebuilt multiple times; current partial reconstruction from early 20th century)
content:
Temple of Vesta
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Temple
Date: 7th century BC (rebuilt multiple times; current partial reconstruction from early 20th century)
Source: self-research
Description
An ancient circular temple (tholos) located near the Regia and the House of the Vestals. The temple housed Vesta's sacred fire, which was a symbol of Rome's safety and prosperity and was tended by the Vestal Virgins. The fire was never allowed to go out; its extinction was seen as a portent of disaster for Rome.

title: Temple of Vespasian and Titus
subtitle: 79-87 AD
content:
Temple of Vespasian and Titus
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Temple
Date: 79-87 AD
Source: self-research
Description
Located at the western end of the Roman Forum between the Temple of Concordia and the Temple of Saturn. Dedicated to the deified Vespasian, it was begun by Titus after Vespasian's death and completed by Domitian. Three elegant Corinthian columns still stand, supporting a section of the ornate entablature with a frieze depicting sacrificial instruments.

title: Temple of Saturn
subtitle: Originally dedicated 497 BC; current ruins from 42 BC reconstruction
content:
Temple of Saturn
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Temple
Date: Originally dedicated 497 BC; current ruins from 42 BC reconstruction
Source: self-research
Description
An ancient Roman temple to the god Saturn, standing at the foot of the Capitoline Hill at the western end of the Roman Forum. Eight impressive columns and part of the entablature remain standing. The temple housed the state treasury (aerarium) and was the focus of the Saturnalia festival, one of the most popular Roman holidays.

title: Temple of Concord
subtitle: 367 BC (traditional); rebuilt 121 BC and again 7 BC-10 AD by Tiberius
content:
Temple of Concord
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Temple
Date: 367 BC (traditional); rebuilt 121 BC and again 7 BC-10 AD by Tiberius
Source: self-research
Description
A series of temples dedicated to the Roman goddess Concordia, located at the western end of the Roman Forum beneath the Capitoline Hill. The final version rebuilt by Tiberius housed an important collection of Greek art. Only the platform and fragments remain today, but the temple's unusual wider-than-deep floor plan is visible.

title: Temple of Castor and Pollux
subtitle: Originally 495 BC; current ruins from 6 AD reconstruction
content:
Temple of Castor and Pollux
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Temple
Date: Originally 495 BC; current ruins from 6 AD reconstruction
Source: self-research
Description
An ancient temple originally built in gratitude for victory at the Battle of Lake Regillus (496 BC), where the divine twins Castor and Pollux were said to have appeared and fought alongside the Romans. Three elegant Corinthian columns remain standing, among the most iconic images of the Roman Forum. The temple served as a meeting place for the Roman Senate and as a depository for weights and measures.

title: Temple of Caesar
subtitle: 29 BC
content:
Temple of Caesar
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Temple
Date: 29 BC
Source: self-research
Description
Also known as the Temple of Divus Iulius, this temple was dedicated to the deified Julius Caesar. Built on the spot where Caesar's body was cremated after his assassination in 44 BC. The altar marks where Mark Antony delivered his famous funeral oration. Romans still leave flowers on the altar today in tribute to Caesar.

title: Temple of Antoninus and Faustina
subtitle: 141 AD
content:
Temple of Antoninus and Faustina
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Temple / Church
Date: 141 AD
Source: self-research
Description
An ancient Roman temple located on the Via Sacra, opposite the Regia. Built by Emperor Antoninus Pius in honor of his deified wife Faustina the Elder, and later also dedicated to the deified Antoninus. Later converted into the Roman Catholic church of San Lorenzo in Miranda, resulting in an exceptionally preserved temple front with massive columns and a complete entablature bearing the original Latin dedication.

title: Tempietto
subtitle: 1502 · Architecture
content:
Tempietto
Wikipedia
Architect: Donato Bramante
Location: San Pietro in Montorio, Rome
Medium: Architecture
Date: 1502
GoogleMap
Description
Marks the start of the High Renaissance in Rome. A small circular commemorative tomb (martyrium) built on the site traditionally believed to be the location of Saint Peter's crucifixion. Considered a masterpiece of High Renaissance Italian architecture, it exemplifies the balance and harmony characteristic of the period.

title: Enthroned Madonna and Child (Tarquinia Madonna)

Also known as the Tarquinia Madonna.

content:
Tabernacle of Orsanmichele

Coronation of the Virgin - The tabernacle includes relief scenes depicting the Assumption and Coronation of the Virgin Mary.

An elaborate marble tabernacle housing the miraculous image of the Madonna.

title: Suburban Baths Erotic Frescoes
subtitle: 62-79 AD · Fresco
content:
Suburban Baths Erotic Frescoes
Wikipedia)
Artist: Unknown Roman painters
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Fresco
Date: 62-79 AD
Source: self-research
Description
Located in the apodyterium (dressing room) of the Suburban Baths near Porta Marina, these are the only set of erotic wall paintings found in a public Roman bath house. Seven sexual scenes and one figure with an enlarged scrotum are depicted above numbered boxes, possibly serving as a humorous method for reminding bathers where they left their clothes. Discovered in 1986.

title: Study of Composition of Last Supper
subtitle: Leonardo da Vinci · Drawing
content:
Study of Composition of Last Supper

Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice

Preparatory study for The Last Supper showing that Judas was originally placed at our side of the table, which is not the case in the final artwork.

title: Studiolo of Francesco I
subtitle: 1570-1572 · Various (paintings, bronzes)
content:
Studiolo of Francesco I
Wikipedia
Artist: Multiple artists under Giorgio Vasari
Location: Palazzo Vecchio, Florence
Medium: Various (paintings, bronzes)
Date: 1570-1572
Source: self-research
Description
A small painting-encrusted barrel-vaulted room commissioned by Francesco I de' Medici. The intimate space features over 30 paintings by various Mannerist artists and eight bronze statuettes, designed as a cabinet of curiosities. The iconographic program was devised by the scholar Vincenzo Borghini.

title: Story of Noah
subtitle: Paolo Uccello · c. 1447 · Fresco

Story of Noah

Story of Noah - Scenes from Genesis 6-9, including the great flood sent by God to cleanse the earth of wickedness, Noah's construction of the ark, and the eventual receding of the waters.

Fresco depicting scenes from the Story of Noah in the Chiostro Verde (Green Cloister), demonstrating Uccello's fascination with perspective.

title: St. Sylvester Sealing the Dragon's Mouth
subtitle: Maso di Banco · c. 1340 · Fresco
content:
St. Sylvester Sealing the Dragon's Mouth

Full title: "St. Sylvester sealing the dragon's mouth and resuscitating two pagan magicians." Created by Maso di Banco, who was an assistant of Giotto.

St. Peter Martyr

A late work by Carpaccio, originally part of a polyptych from Santa Fosca church.

title: St. Mark Preaching in Alexandria

St. Mark Preaching in Alexandria

A collaboration between the Bellini brothers, showing St. Mark preaching to a crowd in Alexandria, Egypt. Notable for its exotic Eastern setting and architectural details.

St. Mark

Spandrel Victories and River Gods

subtitle: Andrea Pisano · 1330–1336 · Bronze
content:
South Door of Florence Baptistery

John the Baptist - The doors depict scenes from the life of John the Baptist, the patron saint of Florence.

The earliest of the three bronze door sets for the Baptistery. The doors contain 28 quatrefoil panels depicting scenes from the life of John the Baptist and allegorical figures of the Virtues.

title: Sixtus IV Appointing Platina as Prefect of the Vatican Library
subtitle: Melozzo da Forlì · 1477 · Fresco (transferred to canvas)
content:
Sixtus IV Appointing Platina as Prefect of the Vatican Library

First surviving papal ceremonial portrait of the Renaissance. Notable for Melozzo's characteristic use of foreshortening.

title: Sistine Chapel Frescoes (Santa Maria Maggiore)
subtitle: Cesare Nebbia · 1587–1589 · Fresco
content:
Sistine Chapel Frescoes (Santa Maria Maggiore)
Artist: Cesare Nebbia and Giovanni Guerra (directors), with a large team of Mannerist painters
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1587–1589
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Assumption of Mary - Mary taken bodily to heaven.
Description
The Sistine Chapel of Santa Maria Maggiore (not to be confused with the Vatican Sistine Chapel) was commissioned by Pope Sixtus V and designed by Domenico Fontana. The interior frescoes were directed by Cesare Nebbia and Giovanni Guerra, depicting scenes from the life of the Virgin and Christ's childhood. The dome fresco shows the Assumption of the Virgin. The chapel also houses the tomb of Pope Sixtus V and an ancient relic believed to be pieces of the crib of the Nativity.

title: Sforza Chapel
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1564–1573 · Architecture with travertine and plaster
content:
Sforza Chapel
Artist: Michelangelo (design), Tiberio Calcagni and Giacomo Della Porta (execution)
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Architecture with travertine and plaster
Date: c. 1564–1573
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Assumption of Mary - The altar painting depicts the Assumption of the Virgin by Girolamo Siciolante da Sermoneta.
Description
Designed by Michelangelo near the end of his life and completed posthumously by Tiberio Calcagni and Giacomo Della Porta. The chapel features an innovative elliptical plan with a three-part vault and curving side apses, representing one of Michelangelo's most forward-looking architectural experiments.

title: Separation of Light from Darkness
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1512 · Fresco
content:
Separation of Light from Darkness
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1512
Biblical Context
Creation - God separates light from darkness on the first day of creation (Genesis 1:3-5).
Description
Completed in 1 day—the fastest execution of any panel on the ceiling. The only scene that is presented as if viewed from below, with dramatic foreshortening of God's figure. This is the first act of creation, showing God's hands separating the primordial light from darkness.

title: Philosophy (The School of Athens)
subtitle: Raphael · 1509-1511 · Fresco
content:
Philosophy (The School of Athens)
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1509-1511
Description
The building depicted is not a real one but an invention. The statues in the left and right are Apollo and Minerva, gods of the arts and wisdom.
In the center stand Plato and Aristotle:
Aristotle holds his Nicomachean Ethics, which stresses the rational nature of humanity and the need for moral behavior. His hand is placed horizontally to indicate the earth is the source for his observation.
Plato holds his Timaeus, in which he describes the origin of the universe. He points upward to indicate that his ideas come from the realm of the mind.
Key figures identified:
Socrates is in a green robe at the left of Plato
Pythagoras at the lower left demonstrates his system of proportions
Ptolemy at the extreme right contemplates a celestial globe
Euclid at the left of Ptolemy bends down to draw a circle—this is a portrait of Bramante
At the extreme right, Raphael painted a self-portrait looking out
In the foreground sits a lonely man with 16th century stone cutter boots—a portrait of Michelangelo

title: Schola Cantorum

Schola Cantorum

Location: Santa Maria in Cosmedin, Rome
Medium: Marble with Cosmatesque decoration

Description
An enclosed choir area in the nave with intricately carved marble panels featuring Cosmatesque geometric inlay. Part of a larger ensemble of 13th-century marble liturgical furnishings including the pulpit, paschal candlestick, and episcopal throne (bishop's chair with three steps and lion-carved armrests).

title: "Sappho" Fresco
subtitle: 1st century AD · Fresco
content:
"Sappho" Fresco
Wikipedia)

Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania (original location; now at National Archaeological Museum, Naples)

Source: self-research
Description
Also known as Portrait of a Young Woman with Stylus, this fresco depicts a finely dressed young woman with a writing tablet and stylus, indicating literacy and education. Recovered in 1760, it is displayed at the National Archaeological Museum, Naples, alongside the Portrait of Terentius Neo. Executed in the Fourth Style of Pompeian painting.

title: Santa Maria Novella Facade

content:
Santa Maria Novella Facade
Wikipedia
Artist: Alberti
Location: Santa Maria Novella, Florence
Medium: Architecture (marble)
Date: 1456–1470
Description
The facade of Santa Maria Novella, designed by Alberti. The only green and white marble structure in Florence.

San Marco Altarpiece
Wikipedia

Date: c. 1438–1443
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus and saints, representing the Incarnation of God.
Description
Major altarpiece for the church of San Marco in Florence.

title: San Giobbe Altarpiece
subtitle: Giovanni Bellini · c. 1487 · Oil on panel
content:
San Giobbe Altarpiece
Wikipedia
Artist: Giovanni Bellini
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice

Description
A sacra conversazione (sacred conversation) altarpiece showing the Madonna and Child with saints.

title: Salus Populi Romani
subtitle: Uncertain, possibly 5th–9th century · Tempera on panel (Byzantine icon)
content:
Salus Populi Romani
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown (attributed by tradition to Saint Luke)
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Tempera on panel (Byzantine icon)
Date: Uncertain, possibly 5th–9th century
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
A venerated Byzantine icon of the Madonna and Child kept in the Borghese (Pauline) Chapel. The image shows the Virgin holding the Christ Child, who holds a Gospel book. Tradition attributes it to Saint Luke the Evangelist. It is one of the most revered Marian icons in Rome and has been a particular devotion of Pope Francis. The icon was restored in 2018.

title: Saint Matthew
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1506 · Marble (unfinished)
content:
Saint Matthew
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Galleria dell'Accademia, Florence
Medium: Marble (unfinished)
Date: c. 1506
Source: my-study, self-research
Description
One of a series of 12 apostle statues commissioned for the interior of the Florence Cathedral (Duomo) that was never begun. This unfinished work shows Michelangelo's sculptural process—the figure appears to be emerging from the block of marble, demonstrating his concept that the sculptor's task is to liberate the form already present within the stone.

title: Saint Mark Enthroned
subtitle: Titian · 1510-1511 · Oil on panel
content:
Saint Mark Enthroned
Wikipedia
Artist: Titian
Location: Santa Maria della Salute, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: 1510-1511
Source: self-research
Description
The altarpiece of the sacristy, originally painted for Santo Spirito in Isola. Saint Mark sits enthroned holding his gospel, flanked by Saints Cosmas and Damian (patron saints of physicians) on the left, and Saints Roch and Sebastian (saints invoked during plague) on the right. Thought to be Titian's first independent commission.

title: Saint Mark
subtitle: Donatello · 1411-1413 · Marble
content:
Saint Mark
Wikipedia)
Artist: Donatello
Location: Orsanmichele, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: 1411-1413
Source: self-research
Description
A marble statue standing approximately 7 ft 9 in (2.36 m) high, commissioned by the linen-drapers' guild (Arte dei Linaioli e Rigattieri). It depicts Mark the Evangelist with extraordinary naturalism in the drapery and pose. The figure stands in a confident contrapposto, with weight shifted to one leg, creating a sense of life and movement.
The statue originally was displayed in an exterior niche of the church, where a copy now stands. The original has been moved inside the building, which is now a museum. Michelangelo reportedly said that he had "never seen a figure with more of the appearance of a good man than this."

title: Saint John the Baptist
subtitle: Lorenzo Ghiberti · 1412-1416 · Bronze
content:
Saint John the Baptist
Wikipedia)
Artist: Lorenzo Ghiberti
Location: Orsanmichele, Florence
Medium: Bronze
Date: 1412-1416
Source: self-research
Description
A bronze statue commissioned by the cloth merchant's guild (Arte di Calimala). The first life-sized bronze cast in the Renaissance and the first bronze statue of its size to be cast in a single piece for several hundred years in Italy.
The artist's use of unnaturalistic but elegant curves in the hair and drapery of the saint show the influence of the International Gothic style prevalent in Italy at the time the work was created. The statue marks an important technical achievement in bronze casting and helped establish Ghiberti's reputation, leading to his famous commission for the Baptistery doors.

title: Saint John the Baptist
subtitle: Donatello · 1438 · Painted wood
content:
Saint John the Baptist
Wikipedia)
Artist: Donatello
Location: Basilica di Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari, Venice
Medium: Painted wood
Date: 1438
Source: self-research
Description
The only statue by Donatello still in Venice. This wooden sculpture was restored in 1973, revealing the artist's signature with the date 1438. Located in the Cappella di San Giovanni Battista.

title: Saint Jerome Writing
subtitle: Caravaggio · c. 1605–1606 · Oil on canvas
content:
Saint Jerome Writing
Wikipedia
Artist: Caravaggio
Location: Galleria Borghese, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1605–1606
Source: self-research
Description
A contemplative depiction of the Church Father Saint Jerome at his desk, writing with dramatic chiaroscuro lighting. The elderly saint is shown with his traditional attributes including a skull and books.

title: Saint Bruno
subtitle: Jean-Antoine Houdon · 1766-1767 · Marble sculpture
content:
Saint Bruno
Wikipedia
Artist: Jean-Antoine Houdon
Location: Baths of Diocletian, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: 1766-1767
Source: self-research
Description
A neoclassical marble statue of Saint Bruno, founder of the Carthusian Order, created by the French sculptor Houdon during his time at the French Academy in Rome. The serene, contemplative figure is considered one of Houdon's masterpieces. Pope Clement XIV reportedly remarked that the statue "would speak, were it not that the rules of his order impose silence."

title: Sacred and Profane Love
subtitle: Titian · c. 1514 · Oil on canvas
content:
Sacred and Profane Love
Wikipedia
Artist: Titian
Location: Galleria Borghese, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1514
Source: self-research
Description
An early masterpiece probably commissioned to celebrate a wedding. The allegorical painting depicts a clothed woman and a nude woman (possibly representing earthly and divine love) seated at a sarcophagus fountain with Cupid.

title: Madonna and Child (Rucellai Madonna)
subtitle: Duccio · 1285 · Tempera on panel
content:
Madonna and Child (Rucellai Madonna)
Artist: Duccio
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: 1285
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus, representing the Incarnation of God.
