A masterpiece of Sienese painting from the early Trecento.

title: Rostra
subtitle: Various dates; main platform moved to current location 44 BC by Julius Caesar
content:
Rostra
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Speakers' Platform
Date: Various dates; main platform moved to current location 44 BC by Julius Caesar
Source: self-research
Description
A large platform from which orators addressed the Roman people. The name comes from the ships' prows (rostra) that decorated the front after a naval victory. Cicero delivered many of his famous speeches here, and after his murder, his head and hands were displayed on the Rostra. Mark Antony's funeral oration for Caesar was likely delivered from here.

title: Rose Window
subtitle: Andrea da Firenze · c. 1365 · Stained glass
content:
Rose Window
Artist: Andrea da Firenze
Location: Santa Maria Novella, Florence
Medium: Stained glass
Date: c. 1365
Description
Stained glass rose window imported from France.

title: Room of the Masks Frescoes
subtitle: c. 30 BC · Fresco (Second Style Roman wall painting)
content:
Room of the Masks Frescoes
Artist: Unknown
Location: Palatine Hill, Rome (House of Augustus)
Medium: Fresco (Second Style Roman wall painting)
Date: c. 30 BC
Source: self-research
Description
Perspective architectural paintings and theatrical masks in the western rooms of the House of Augustus, representing the Second Style of Roman wall painting. The illusionistic architectural scenes create the impression of views through walls into elaborate stage sets. These frescoes are among the finest surviving examples of Second Style painting, demonstrating the Roman mastery of perspective and trompe-l'oeil techniques.

title: Relief of the Virgin Showing Soldiers the Spring
subtitle: c. 1758 · Marble relief
content:
Relief of the Virgin Showing Soldiers the Spring
Artist: Andrea Bergondi
Location: Trevi Fountain, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. 1758
Source: self-research
Description
Positioned above the right niche, this bas-relief illustrates the legend that gave the Aqua Virgo its name. A young maiden (virgo) leads Roman soldiers to a pure spring, which became the source for the aqueduct.

title: Relief of Agrippa Approving the Aqueduct Plans
subtitle: c. 1758 · Marble relief
content:
Relief of Agrippa Approving the Aqueduct Plans
Artist: Giovanni Battista Grossi
Location: Trevi Fountain, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. 1758
Source: self-research
Description
Located above the left niche, this bas-relief depicts the Roman general Marcus Agrippa approving the construction plans for the Aqua Virgo aqueduct in 19 BC. The relief commemorates the historical origins of the water supply that feeds the fountain.

title: Regia
subtitle: 8th century BC (original); multiple rebuildings
content:
Regia
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Royal/Religious Building
Date: 8th century BC (original); multiple rebuildings
Source: self-research
Description
A two-part structure along the Via Sacra that originally served as the residence or headquarters of the Roman kings, later becoming the office of the pontifex maximus (chief priest). Only foundations remain. Archaeological excavations have revealed multiple layers of rebuilding, making this one of the most important sites for understanding early Roman history.

title: The Rape of Proserpina
subtitle: Gian Lorenzo Bernini · 1621–1622 · Marble sculpture
content:
The Rape of Proserpina
Wikipedia
Artist: Gian Lorenzo Bernini
Location: Galleria Borghese, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: 1621–1622
Source: self-research
Mythological Context
Persephone - The abduction of Persephone (Roman: Proserpina) by Hades (Roman: Pluto), god of the underworld. Her annual return to the surface represents the cycle of seasons.
Description
A large Baroque marble group depicting the abduction of Proserpina by Pluto. Completed when Bernini was just 23, it features remarkable technical virtuosity in rendering flesh and movement in marble, with Pluto's fingers pressing into Proserpina's thigh.

title: The Rape of Europa
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · c. 1580 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Rape of Europa
Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1580
Source: self-research
Description
Located in the Sala dell'Anticollegio, this mythological painting depicts the abduction of Europa by Zeus in the form of a white bull. It hangs alongside Tintoretto's allegories.

title: "Quisquis Amat" Inscription
subtitle: Before 79 AD · Graffito (scratched inscription)
content:
"Quisquis Amat" Inscription
Artist: Anonymous
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Graffito (scratched inscription)
Date: Before 79 AD
Source: self-research
Description
A famous inscription lamenting frustrated love: "Quisquis amat valeat, pereat qui nescit amare, bis tanto pereat quisquis amare vetat" ("Whoever loves, let him flourish; let him perish who knows not love; let him perish twice over whoever forbids love"). This graffito captures the passionate sentiments of ancient Romans.

title: Punishment of the Korah, Dathan and Abiram
subtitle: Sandro Botticelli · 1481–1482 · Fresco
content:
Punishment of the Korah, Dathan and Abiram
Wikipedia
Artist: Sandro Botticelli
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1481–1482
Biblical Context
Punishment of Korah - The story from Numbers 16 describes the rebellion of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram against Moses and Aaron. God punished them by having the earth swallow them and fire consume those who offered false incense.
Description
Story narrated from left to right:
In the left, the earth opens up to swallow the rebels
In the center, figures offering false fire to the Lord were consumed by the fire
In the right, Moses seeks refuge from Israelites who stoned him
Moses' forehead ray is from biblical text (Exodus 34:29-35)

title: Province Personification Reliefs
subtitle: c. 145 CE · Marble relief
content:
Province Personification Reliefs
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors
Location: Temple of Hadrian, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. 145 CE
Source: self-research
Description
A series of marble relief panels depicting personifications of Roman provinces, originally decorating the temple's podium. Nineteen panels survive, showing allegorical female figures representing provinces of the empire alternating with military trophies. Sixteen province figures remain well preserved, now distributed among five collections in Rome and Naples including the Capitoline Museums and Palazzo Massimo alle Terme.

title: Products of Autumn
subtitle: Francesco Queirolo · c. 1735-1762 · Marble sculpture
content:
Products of Autumn
Artist: Francesco Queirolo
Location: Trevi Fountain, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: c. 1735-1762
Source: self-research
Description
An allegorical figure at the attic level holding grapes and a cup, representing the autumn harvest and the bounty of the vine made possible by fresh water.

title: Procession of the True Cross in Piazza San Marco
subtitle: Gentile Bellini · c. 1496 · Tempera on canvas
content:
Procession of the True Cross in Piazza San Marco
Wikipedia
Artist: Gentile Bellini
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Tempera on canvas
Date: c. 1496
Description
Painted for the scuole (school) of Venice, a religious group. Shows a procession in Piazza San Marco with remarkable architectural detail.

title: Procession of the Magi
subtitle: Benozzo Gozzoli · c. 1459 · Fresco
content:
Procession of the Magi
Wikipedia
Artist: Benozzo Gozzoli
Location: Palazzo Medici Riccardi, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 1459
Biblical Context
Adoration of the Magi - The visit of the three wise men (Magi) from the East who followed a star to Bethlehem to pay homage to the infant Jesus, bringing gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh (Matthew 2:1-12).
Description
Series of murals in the Magi Chapel depicting festive, vibrant processions with fine attention to detail. The Company of the Magi was a religious organization to which the Medici belonged.
The procession of the three Magi unfolds with a mixture of exotic, oriental splendor and stately, bourgeois respectability. A glittering cavalcade of men and animals winds through a rocky landscape under an azure sky, with men dressed in all the luxury of Italian 15th-century fashions, in brilliant colors, damask, and gold brocade. They ride horses and camels with various creatures to amuse them—dogs, cheetahs, and monkeys.
The religious theme was combined with a depiction of several members of the Medici family, their allies, and important figures who arrived in Florence for the Council of Florence (1438-1439). The fresco includes 32 realistic portraits, including Gozzoli himself, whose head is turned with his eye looking out toward the observer.

title: Procession in St. Mark's Square
subtitle: Gentile Bellini · c. 1496 · Tempera on canvas
content:
Procession in St. Mark's Square
Wikipedia
Artist: Gentile Bellini
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Tempera on canvas
Date: c. 1496
Source: self-research
Description
Part of a cycle depicting miracles of the True Cross, this large canvas provides a remarkable view of Piazza San Marco in the 15th century, showing the old mosaics on the basilica facade and contemporary Venetian life in extraordinary detail.

title: Primavera
subtitle: Sandro Botticelli · c. 1477–1482 · Tempera on panel
content:
Primavera
Wikipedia)
Artist: Sandro Botticelli
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1477–1482
Description
Primavera means "Spring." The painting depicts a mythological scene in a garden:
At the right, the wind god Zephyrus pursues the virgin nymph Chloris. Chloris then transforms into Flora, goddess of Spring, shown to her left
At the left, Mercury dispels the storm
At the center stands Venus, goddess of Love, Beauty and Marriage
Links to the Medici: the oranges are similar to the red palle (balls) in the Medici coat of arms. Flames on Mercury and Venus' neck and breasts are the fires of St. Lawrence (Lorenzo).

title: Priapus Fresco (House of the Vettii)
subtitle: After 62 AD · Fresco
content:
Priapus Fresco (House of the Vettii)
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown Roman painter
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Fresco
Date: After 62 AD
Source: self-research
Description
Located in the vestibule of the House of the Vettii, this famous fresco depicts Priapus, the god of fertility, weighing his oversized phallus against a bag of gold coins. The Romans believed Priapus served as a talisman protecting the riches of the house. The fresco was covered with plaster and only rediscovered in 1998 due to rainfall.

title: The Presentation of the Virgin at the Temple
subtitle: Titian · 1534-1538 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Presentation of the Virgin at the Temple
Wikipedia)
Artist: Titian
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1534-1538
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Presentation of Mary - According to tradition, Mary was presented at the Temple in Jerusalem at age three.
Description
A huge painting (335 x 775 cm) depicting the three-year-old Virgin Mary entering the Temple of Jerusalem. Commissioned for the Scuola della Carità and still in its original location, now incorporated into the museum.

title: The Presentation of the Virgin Mary at the Temple
subtitle: Giovanni Francesco Romanelli · 1638-1642 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Presentation of the Virgin Mary at the Temple
Wikipedia
Artist: Giovanni Francesco Romanelli
Location: Baths of Diocletian, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1638-1642
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Presentation of Mary - According to tradition, the young Virgin Mary was presented at the Temple in Jerusalem.
Description
A major Baroque altarpiece originally painted for St. Peter's Basilica, depicting the young Virgin Mary being presented at the Temple in Jerusalem. Considered a highpoint of Romanelli's work, the painting was later transferred to Santa Maria degli Angeli where it hangs in the transept.

title: Portrait of the Four Tetrarchs
subtitle: c. 300 AD · Porphyry sculpture
content:
Portrait of the Four Tetrarchs
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptor
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Porphyry sculpture
Date: c. 300 AD
Source: self-research
Historical Context
Tetramorph - Related to the four living creatures symbolism, though this work depicts the secular Roman Tetrarchy system.
Description
A sculpture group of four Roman emperors dating from the Tetrarchy period. Fixed to the southwest corner of the basilica's facade since the Middle Ages, it was probably looted from the Philadelphion in Constantinople during the Fourth Crusade in 1204. The embracing figures represent the unity of the tetrarchs who ruled the Roman Empire together.

title: Portrait of Terentius Neo
subtitle: c. 50 AD · Fresco
content:
Portrait of Terentius Neo
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown Roman painter
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania (original location; now at National Archaeological Museum, Naples)
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 50 AD
Source: self-research
Description
A Roman fresco depicting a couple holding objects important to literacy—he holds a scroll while she holds a stylus and wax tablet. Found in the House of Terentius Neo, it is considered one of the finest pieces of art from the area of Vesuvius. Now in the National Archaeological Museum, Naples.

title: Portrait of Pietro Aretino
subtitle: Titian · c. 1545 · Oil on canvas
content:
Portrait of Pietro Aretino
Wikipedia
Artist: Titian
Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1545
Source: self-research
Description
A commanding portrait of the Renaissance poet and satirist Pietro Aretino, painted possibly for Cosimo I de' Medici. Titian renders his friend in richly textured robes with bold, almost impressionistic brushwork. Aretino famously complained that the finish was too sketchy, yet the vigorous technique is now admired as proto-modern. Displayed in the Sala di Venere.

title: Portrait of Maddalena Doni
subtitle: Raphael · c. 1506 · Oil on panel
content:
Portrait of Maddalena Doni
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1506
Description
A portrait of Maddalena Strozzi, wife of Agnolo Doni. The composition resembles that of the Mona Lisa, but with more details on the material of cloth and jewels. Painted as a pair with the Portrait of Agnolo Doni.

title: Portrait of Leo X
subtitle: Raphael · c. 1518-1519 · Oil on panel
content:
Portrait of Leo X
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1518-1519
Description
Leo X did not like Michelangelo, so Raphael rose to a level of power and wealth so high no other Italian artist had ever met. Raphael became the papal architect. The portrait shows the pope with cardinals Giulio de' Medici (the future Pope Clement VII) and Luigi de' Rossi.

title: Portrait of Francesco delle Opere
subtitle: Pietro Perugino · 1494 · Oil on panel
content:
Portrait of Francesco delle Opere
Wikipedia
Artist: Pietro Perugino
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: 1494
Description
Considered an ancestor of portraits by Raphael, Perugino's most famous pupil.

title: Portrait of Doge Giovanni Mocenigo
subtitle: Gentile Bellini · c. 1478-1485 · Oil on panel
content:
Portrait of Doge Giovanni Mocenigo
Artist: Gentile Bellini
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1478-1485
Source: self-research
Description
A profile portrait of Doge Giovanni Mocenigo demonstrating Gentile Bellini's skill as the official portrait artist for the Doges of Venice. Giovanni Mocenigo served as doge from 1478 to 1485.

title: Portrait of Agnolo Doni
subtitle: Raphael · c. 1506 · Oil on panel
content:
Portrait of Agnolo Doni
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1506
Description
A portrait of the wealthy Florentine merchant Agnolo Doni (who also commissioned Michelangelo's Doni Tondo). The composition resembles that of the Mona Lisa, but with more details on the material of cloth and jewels. Painted as a pair with the Portrait of Maddalena Doni.

title: Portrait of a Young Englishman
subtitle: Titian · c. 1540–1545 · Oil on canvas
content:
Portrait of a Young Englishman
Wikipedia
Artist: Titian
Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1540–1545
Source: self-research
Description
A striking portrait of an unidentified young man with intense grey-blue eyes, traditionally but uncertainly identified as an Englishman. The sitter may be Henry Howard, Ottavio Farnese, or the Italian Ippolito Riminaldi. The painting is admired for its penetrating psychological insight and Titian's virtuosic handling of the rich dark costume against the grey background.

title: Portrait of a Man with a Medal of Cosimo de Medici
subtitle: Sandro Botticelli · c. 1475 · Tempera on panel
content:
Portrait of a Man with a Medal of Cosimo de Medici
Wikipedia
Artist: Sandro Botticelli
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1475
Description
The man may be Lorenzo di Pierfrancesco, holding a medal depicting Cosimo de' Medici.

title: Portrait of a Lady with Flowers
subtitle: Andrea del Verrocchio · c. 1475–1480 · Marble
content:
Portrait of a Lady with Flowers
Artist: Andrea del Verrocchio
Location: Bargello, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 1475–1480
Description
First three-quarter-length sculpted portrait since antiquity. A landmark in Renaissance portraiture.

title: Plato
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · 1560s · Oil on canvas
content:
Plato
Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Biblioteca Marciana, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1560s
Source: self-research
Description
One of a pair of philosopher portraits by Veronese flanking the entrance portal in the main hall. The side walls feature canvases by various artists representing the Philosophers.

title: Madonna with Child with Scenes of the Life of Saint Anne (Pitti Tondo)
subtitle: Filippo Lippi · c. 1452 · Tempera on panel (tondo)
content:
Madonna with Child with Scenes of the Life of Saint Anne (Pitti Tondo)
Wikipedia
Artist: Filippo Lippi
Location: Pitti Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel (tondo)
Date: c. 1452
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus, representing the Incarnation of God.
Description
A tondo (circular painting) depicting the Madonna and Child with scenes from the life of Saint Anne.

title: Pippo Spano
subtitle: Andrea del Castagno · c. 1450 · Fresco (detached)
content:
Pippo Spano
Wikipedia)
Artist: Andrea del Castagno
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Fresco (detached)
Date: c. 1450
Description
Portrait of Filippo Scolari, known as Pippo Spano. Born in Florence, he became a general of King Sigismund and fought in the Hussite Wars, where he was beaten by Jan Žižka.

title: Pietà
subtitle: Titian · 1575-1576 · Oil on canvas
content:
Pietà
Wikipedia)
Artist: Titian
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1575-1576
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Pietà - The scene of the Virgin Mary mourning over the body of Christ after the Crucifixion.
Description
One of Titian's last paintings, left incomplete at his death in 1576 and finished by Palma Giovane. Titian intended it for his own grave. A profoundly moving late work demonstrating the artist's loose, expressive brushwork in his final years.

title: Pietà
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1498-1499 · Marble
content:
Pietà
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: St. Peter's Basilica, Vatican
Medium: Marble
Date: 1498-1499
Biblical Context
Lamentation - The mourning over Christ's body after his death on the cross.
Description
Created when Michelangelo was only 23 years old. The sculpture was designed to be placed on or near the floor, so the viewer can see Christ's face better. It is the only work Michelangelo ever signed, reportedly after overhearing viewers attribute it to another sculptor.

title: Pietà
subtitle: Giovanni Bellini · c. 1460s · Oil on panel
content:
Pietà
Artist: Giovanni Bellini
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1460s
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Pietà - The Virgin Mary cradling the dead body of Christ after the Crucifixion.
Description
An atmospheric composition echoing Donatello's bronze relief. Part of the museum's significant collection of Bellini family works.

title: Pietà
subtitle: Giovanni Bellini · c. 1465–1470 · Tempera on panel
content:
Pietà
Wikipedia
Artist: Giovanni Bellini
Location: Pinacoteca di Brera, Milan
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1465–1470
Biblical Context
Lamentation - The Virgin Mary mourning over the body of Christ after the Crucifixion. While not directly described in scripture, it is derived from the burial accounts and represents the sorrow of Mary.
Description
An intimate depiction of the dead Christ supported by the Virgin Mary.

title: Pietà
subtitle: Cosmè Tura · c. 1460 · Tempera on panel
content:
Pietà
Wikipedia)
Artist: Cosmè Tura
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1460
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Pietà - The Virgin Mary cradling the dead body of Christ after the Crucifixion.
Description
A significant work demonstrating Tura's monumentality and pathos, bequeathed to the museum as part of Teodoro Correr's original collection in 1830. Measures 47.7 cm by 33.5 cm. Initially attributed to Luca d'Olanda until Vincenzo Lazari recognized it as a Tura work in 1859.

title: Pietà
subtitle: Antonello da Messina · c. 1474-1476 · Oil on panel
content:
Pietà
Artist: Antonello da Messina
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1474-1476
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Pietà - The Virgin Mary cradling the dead body of Christ after the Crucifixion.
Description
The only work by Antonello da Messina remaining in Venice from his 1474-76 stay in the city. Originally housed in the Doge's Palace. This work was influential in introducing Flemish oil painting techniques to Venice.

title: Pesaro Madonna
subtitle: Titian · 1519-1526 · Oil on canvas
content:
Pesaro Madonna
Wikipedia
Artist: Titian
Location: Basilica di Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1519-1526
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
Located in the left nave, this revolutionary painting places the Madonna and Child dramatically off-center to the upper right rather than in the physical center. Commissioned by Bishop Jacopo Pesaro, this asymmetrical arrangement was highly innovative and influenced religious painting for generations.

title: The Pentecost
subtitle: Titian · c. 1545 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Pentecost
Artist: Titian
Location: Santa Maria della Salute, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1545
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Pentecost - The descent of the Holy Spirit upon the apostles fifty days after Easter.
Description
A large painting in the nave depicting the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the apostles. One of several Titian works transferred to the Salute from suppressed churches.

title: Pentecost Cupola Mosaic
subtitle: 12th century · Gold and glass mosaic
content:
Pentecost Cupola Mosaic
Artist: Byzantine and Venetian mosaicists
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Gold and glass mosaic
Date: 12th century
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Pentecost - The descent of the Holy Spirit upon the Apostles fifty days after Easter.
Description
The westernmost dome of the nave depicting the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the Apostles at Pentecost. Flames descend from a central dove representing the Holy Spirit, with the Apostles arranged in a radial composition below.

title: Penitent Magdalene
subtitle: Donatello · c. 1440 · Wood (polychrome)
content:
Penitent Magdalene
Wikipedia)
Artist: Donatello
Location: Opera del Duomo Museum, Florence
Medium: Wood (polychrome)
Date: c. 1440
Source: my-study, self-research
Biblical Context
Mary Magdalene - Mary Magdalene as a penitent figure, based on the medieval tradition that conflated her with the unnamed sinful woman in Luke.
Description
A powerful wooden sculpture of Mary Magdalene, probably commissioned for the Florence Baptistery. The piece was received with astonishment for its unprecedented realism, depicting the penitent saint as an emaciated, aging figure. Late work by Donatello demonstrating his expressive late style.

title: Pauline (Borghese) Chapel Frescoes
subtitle: Giuseppe Cesari (Cavalier d'Arpino) · 1605–1616 · Fresco
content:
Pauline (Borghese) Chapel Frescoes
Artist: Giuseppe Cesari (Cavalier d'Arpino), Cigoli (Ludovico Cardi), Guido Reni
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1605–1616
Source: self-research
Description
The Pauline or Borghese Chapel was commissioned by Pope Paul V and designed by Flaminio Ponzio. The lavish interior features frescoes by multiple artists: Giuseppe Cesari painted the dome panels and lunette above the altar; Cigoli painted the Virgin and apostles in the dome; and Guido Reni painted the side arches including powerful depictions of St. Dominic and St. Francis. The chapel houses the Salus Populi Romani icon and the tombs of Popes Clement VIII and Paul V. Pietro Bernini contributed dynamic sculptures framing the altar.

title: Poetry (The Parnassus)
subtitle: Raphael · 1509-1510 · Fresco
content:
Poetry (The Parnassus)
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1509-1510
Description
Apollo in the center leads a band of writers that includes Dante, Homer, and Sappho. The fresco celebrates poetry and represents Mount Parnassus, the mythological home of the Muses.

title: Panciatichi Assumption
subtitle: Andrea del Sarto · c. 1522–1523 · Oil on panel
content:
Panciatichi Assumption
Wikipedia
Artist: Andrea del Sarto
Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1522–1523
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Assumption of Mary - The belief that Mary was taken up body and soul into heavenly glory at the end of her earthly life.
Description
A majestic Assumption of the Virgin painted for the Panciatichi family, showing the Virgin Mary ascending to heaven surrounded by angels, with apostles gathered around the empty tomb below. The work demonstrates Andrea del Sarto's refined spatial composition and experimental use of color that influenced the next generation of Mannerist painters.

title: Palestrina Pietà
subtitle: c. 1555 · Marble
content:
Palestrina Pietà
Wikipedia
Artist: Attributed to Michelangelo (disputed)
Location: Galleria dell'Accademia, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 1555
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Lamentation (Pietà) - The mourning over Christ's body after the Crucifixion.
Description
A marble sculpture depicting the dead Christ supported by the Virgin Mary and another figure. Formerly attributed to Michelangelo, but now considered to have possibly been completed by someone else, such as Niccolò Menghini or Gian Lorenzo Bernini. The attribution remains controversial.

title: Palazzo Rucellai
subtitle: Alberti · c. 1446–1451 · Architecture
content:
Palazzo Rucellai
Wikipedia
Artist: Alberti
Location: Palazzo Rucellai, Florence
Medium: Architecture
Date: c. 1446–1451
Description
Renaissance palace designed by Leon Battista Alberti for the Rucellai family.

title: Pala d'Oro
subtitle: 10th-14th century (created in phases) · Gold, enamel, precious gems
content:
Pala d'Oro
Wikipedia
Artist: Byzantine craftsmen
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Gold, enamel, precious gems
Date: 10th-14th century (created in phases)
Source: self-research
Description
The high altar retable of the Basilica, universally recognized as one of the most refined works of Byzantine enamel. Adorned with 1,927 precious gems including 526 pearls, 330 garnets, 320 emeralds, 255 sapphires, and 75 rubies. The jewel-encrusted altarpiece depicts scenes from the life of Christ and took 366 years to complete.

title: Ovid's Heroides Reference
subtitle: Before 79 AD · Graffito (scratched inscription)
content:
Ovid's Heroides Reference
Artist: Anonymous
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Graffito (scratched inscription)
Date: Before 79 AD
Source: self-research
Description
An unusual literary inscription referencing Ovid's Heroides 4, the poem about Phaedra falling in love with her stepson Hippolytus. This graffito was found near a painting, suggesting an educated viewer engaged with the artwork through literary association—evidence of sophisticated cultural dialogue in ancient Pompeii.

title: Ospedale degli Innocenti
subtitle: Brunelleschi · 1419–1445 · Architecture
content:
Ospedale degli Innocenti
Wikipedia
Artist: Brunelleschi
Location: Ospedale degli Innocenti, Florence
Medium: Architecture
Date: 1419–1445
Description
Hospital of the Innocents, designed by Brunelleschi. Provided orphans and children with housing and education until age 18. Children were given the last name "Innocenti."

title: Old Sacristy (Sagrestia Vecchia)
subtitle: Filippo Brunelleschi · 1421–1428 · Architecture
content:
Old Sacristy (Sagrestia Vecchia)
Wikipedia
Artist: Filippo Brunelleschi
Location: San Lorenzo, Florence
Medium: Architecture
Date: 1421–1428
Description
One of the earliest Renaissance interiors. Commissioned by Giovanni di Bicci de' Medici as a new sacristy for the old church of San Lorenzo.

title: Madonna Enthroned (Ognissanti Madonna)
subtitle: Giotto · c. 1306–1310 · Tempera on panel
content:
Madonna Enthroned (Ognissanti Madonna)
Wikipedia
Artist: Giotto
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1306–1310
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus, representing the Incarnation of God.
Description
One of Giotto's masterpieces, showing his revolutionary approach to naturalism and three-dimensionality.

title: Oceanus (Neptune)
subtitle: Pietro Bracci · 1761-1762 · Marble sculpture
content:
Oceanus (Neptune)
Artist: Pietro Bracci, after a model by Giovanni Battista Maini
Location: Trevi Fountain, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: 1761-1762
Source: self-research
Description
The colossal central figure of the fountain, depicting Oceanus (the personification of all seas and oceans) standing in an oyster-shell chariot. The god commands the waters with a gesture of authority. Bracci carved the marble sculpture based on a plaster modello by Maini, who died before completing the work.

title: North Sacristy Intarsia
subtitle: Giuliano da Maiano · c. 1463–1465 · Intarsia (wood inlay)
content:
North Sacristy Intarsia
Artist: Giuliano da Maiano
Location: Florence Cathedral, Florence
Medium: Intarsia (wood inlay)
Date: c. 1463–1465
Description
Intarsia decoration in the North Sacristy of Florence Cathedral. Intarsia is a form of wood inlaying using variously colored pieces of wood to create images.

title: North Door of Florence Baptistery
subtitle: Lorenzo Ghiberti · 1403–1424 · Bronze
content:
North Door of Florence Baptistery
Wikipedia
Artist: Lorenzo Ghiberti
Location: Florence Baptistery, Florence
Medium: Bronze
Date: 1403–1424
Source: my-study, self-research
Description
Ghiberti's first masterpiece, made before his celebrated Gates of Paradise. The doors contain scenes from the New Testament in quatrefoil frames. After restoration in 2013-2015, the original doors were displayed in the Museo dell'Opera del Duomo and replaced by a copy on the Baptistery. Created after Ghiberti won the famous competition against Brunelleschi.

title: Equestrian Monument of Niccolò da Tolentino
subtitle: Andrea del Castagno · 1456 · Fresco
content:
Equestrian Monument of Niccolò da Tolentino
Wikipedia
Artist: Andrea del Castagno
Location: Florence Cathedral, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1456
Source: my-study, self-research
Description
A painted equestrian monument honoring the Italian condottiero Niccolò da Tolentino. Located on the left internal wall of the church next to the earlier fresco of John Hawkwood by Paolo Uccello. Both frescoes simulate three-dimensional sculptural monuments through illusionistic painting.

title: Nave Mosaics
subtitle: c. 432–440 · Mosaic
content:
Nave Mosaics
Artist: Unknown
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Mosaic
Date: c. 432–440
Source: self-research
Description
A cycle of Old Testament narrative mosaics lining the nave, depicting scenes from the lives of Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, and Joshua. Only 27 of the original 42 panels survive. They are the most important Early Christian narrative mosaic series extant, executed in a late Roman illusionistic style with rich gold backgrounds.

title: Nativity Sculptures
subtitle: Arnolfo di Cambio · c. 1291 · Marble sculpture
content:
Nativity Sculptures
Artist: Arnolfo di Cambio
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: c. 1291
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Nativity - The birth of Jesus in Bethlehem.
Description
A group of 13th-century marble sculptures depicting the Nativity scene, originally part of a larger sculptural ensemble for the Oratory of the Nativity (Presepe). The figures include the Virgin Mary, Joseph, the ox, the ass, and the Magi. They are among the earliest known freestanding Nativity sculptural groups and are now displayed in the underground museum chapel of the basilica.

title: Music (La Musica)
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · 1556-1557 · Oil on canvas
content:
Music (La Musica)
Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Biblioteca Marciana, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Dimensions: 230 cm diameter (tondo)
Date: 1556-1557
Source: self-research
Description
Depicts beautiful young women playing string instruments—viola da gamba, lute, and harpsichord—with a third woman singing and Cupid shown under a marble statue of a faun. This work was judged the best tondo in the ceiling and earned Veronese a prize of a gold chain, as judged by Titian and Sansovino.

title: Moses
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1513-1515 · Marble
content:
Moses
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Basilica of San Pietro in Vincoli, Rome
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 1513-1515
Description
Moses holds the Tablets of the Law. Part of the tomb of Pope Julius II, though the tomb was never completed as originally designed. The left arm repeats almost the same pose as the Cumaean Sibyl in the Sistine Chapel. The face looks similar to the God figure in the Creation of Sun, Moon and Plants in the Sistine Chapel.
The horns on Moses' head derive from a mistranslation in the Latin Vulgate Bible, where the Hebrew word for "rays of light" was rendered as "horns" (cornuta). Moses is depicted at the moment of descending from Mount Sinai, about to discover the Israelites worshipping the Golden Calf.

title: Monument to Titian
subtitle: 1852 · Marble
content:
Monument to Titian
Artist: Luigi Zandomeneghi and others
Location: Basilica di Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari, Venice
Medium: Marble
Date: 1852
Source: self-research
Description
A large 19th-century monument marking Titian's burial place, including a relief version of the Assumption. Titian died of plague in 1576 and was buried here despite plague regulations normally requiring burial elsewhere.

title: Miracle of the Relic of the Cross at the Ponte di Rialto
subtitle: Vittore Carpaccio · c. 1496 · Tempera on canvas
content:
Miracle of the Relic of the Cross at the Ponte di Rialto
Wikipedia
Artist: Vittore Carpaccio
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Tempera on canvas
Date: c. 1496
Source: self-research
Description
Also known as The Healing of the Madman, this painting depicts a miracle of the True Cross relic, showing the old wooden Rialto Bridge and providing invaluable documentation of 15th-century Venetian architecture and daily life.

title: Minerva Protecting Peace and Abundance from Mars
subtitle: Tintoretto · c. 1578 · Oil on canvas
content:
Minerva Protecting Peace and Abundance from Mars
Artist: Tintoretto
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1578
Source: self-research
Description
Also called "Pallas Pushes Mars Away." Part of the Sala dell'Anticollegio cycle, this allegory shows Minerva (goddess of wisdom) defending Peace and Prosperity from Mars (god of war), symbolizing Venice's wise governance that maintains peace and plenty.

title: Meta Sudans
subtitle: c. AD 89-96 · Brick and concrete
content:
Meta Sudans
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown Roman architects
Location: Colosseum, Rome
Medium: Brick and concrete
Date: c. AD 89-96
Source: self-research
Description
A large monumental conical fountain that once stood near the Colosseum in ancient Rome. The fountain "sweated" water from its surface, hence the name. Its remains were visible until 1936 when they were demolished during Mussolini's urban renewal of the area.

title: Mercury and the Three Graces
subtitle: Tintoretto · c. 1578 · Oil on canvas
content:
Mercury and the Three Graces
Artist: Tintoretto
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1578
Source: self-research
Mythological Context
Three Graces - The Charites (Aglaea, Euphrosyne, and Thalia) were goddesses of charm, beauty, and joy in Greek mythology.
Description
One of four mythological allegories in the Sala dell'Anticollegio representing the virtues of the Venetian Republic. Mercury, messenger of the gods, is surrounded by the Three Graces who personify beauty, charm, and joy. Originally in the Atrio Quadrato, moved to the Anticollegio in 1713.

title: The Meeting of Leo the Great and Attila
subtitle: Raphael · 1514 · Fresco
content:
The Meeting of Leo the Great and Attila
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1514
Description
Depicts the meeting between Pope Leo I and Attila the Hun, which took place in 452 in northern Italy. Saints Peter and Paul are the ones flying in the sky, shown as divine protectors of the Church who frightened Attila into retreat.

title: Medici Chapels
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1520-1534 · Architecture and marble sculpture
content:
Medici Chapels
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo (Sagrestia Nuova)
Location: Basilica of San Lorenzo, Florence
Medium: Architecture and marble sculpture
Date: 1520-1534
Source: self-research
Description
Two chapels built between the 16th and 17th centuries as an extension to the Basilica of San Lorenzo. They are the Sagrestia Nuova (New Sacristy), designed by Michelangelo, and the larger Cappella dei Principi (Chapel of the Princes), a collaboration between the Medici family and architects. The purpose of the chapels was to celebrate the Medici family, patrons of the church and Grand Dukes of Tuscany.
The Sagrestia Nuova was Michelangelo's first realization of architecture. He served as both architect and sculptor, creating a unified artistic vision. The New Sacristy contains the celebrated Medici tombs with their allegorical figures of Day, Night, Dawn, and Dusk.

title: Mausoleum of Maxentius
subtitle: Early 4th century AD
content:
Mausoleum of Maxentius
Wikipedia
Location: Via Appia Antica, Rome
Type: Imperial Mausoleum
Date: Early 4th century AD
Source: self-research
Description
A large circular tomb built by Emperor Maxentius on the Appian Way, probably intended for himself as a family tomb. When his young son Valerius Romulus died, he was buried there. After extensive renovation, the mausoleum was reopened to the public in 2014.

title: The Mass at Bolsena
subtitle: Raphael · 1512 · Fresco
content:
The Mass at Bolsena
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1512
Description
A Bohemian priest who doubted the doctrine of transubstantiation was celebrating mass at Bolsena, when the bread began to bleed in the shape of a cross. Below kneel the officers of the Swiss troops. Pope Julius II appears kneeling in prayer, witnessing the miracle.

title: Marzocco
subtitle: Donatello · 1419-1420 · Sandstone (pietra serena)
content:
Marzocco
Wikipedia
Artist: Donatello
Location: Bargello, Florence
Medium: Sandstone (pietra serena)
Date: 1419-1420
Source: self-research
Description
The Marzocco is the heraldic lion that is a symbol of Florence. Donatello's version was apparently the first piece of public secular sculpture commissioned by the Republic of Florence, in the late 14th century. The lion originally stood at the heart of the city in the Piazza della Signoria at the end of the platform attached to the Palazzo Vecchio called the ringhiera, from which speakers traditionally harangued the crowd.
This iconic representation of Florentine civic pride holds a shield bearing the lily emblem of Florence. The original is now in the Bargello, with a copy in the original location.

title: The Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian
subtitle: Domenichino · 1629 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian
Wikipedia
Artist: Domenichino
Location: Baths of Diocletian, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1629
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Saint Sebastian - The martyrdom of Saint Sebastian, an early Christian saint tied to a post and shot with arrows during the Diocletianic Persecution.
Description
One of the most celebrated paintings in the basilica, originally painted for the altar of St. Sebastian in St. Peter's Basilica. The dramatic composition shows Jesus Christ welcoming the martyr saint while an angel descends bearing the palm and crown of martyrdom. The painting was transferred to Santa Maria degli Angeli in the 18th century.

title: Martelli Annunciation
subtitle: Filippo Lippi · c. 1440 · Tempera on panel
content:
Martelli Annunciation
Wikipedia
Artist: Filippo Lippi
Location: San Lorenzo, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1440
Biblical Context
Annunciation - The moment when the Angel Gabriel announced to the Virgin Mary that she would conceive and bear the Son of God, as described in Luke 1:26-38.
Description
Annunciation scene created for the Martelli family.

title: Mars and Neptune
subtitle: Jacopo Sansovino · 1567 · Marble sculpture
content:
Mars and Neptune
Artist: Jacopo Sansovino
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: 1567
Source: self-research
Description
Two colossal statues guarding the Giants' Staircase (Scala dei Giganti). Mars represents Venice's power by land, Neptune her power by sea. The statues flank the staircase where doges were crowned.

title: The Marriage of the Virgin
subtitle: Raphael · 1504 · Oil on panel
content:
The Marriage of the Virgin
Wikipedia)
Artist: Raphael
Location: Brera, Milan
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: 1504
Description
Shows large influence from his teacher Perugino—compare to Perugino's Delivery of the Keys, which has similar figures, ground, and architecture. The painting depicts the marriage of the Virgin Mary to Joseph.

title: Marriage at Cana
subtitle: Tintoretto · 1561 · Oil on canvas
content:
Marriage at Cana
Artist: Tintoretto
Location: Santa Maria della Salute, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1561
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Marriage at Cana - Jesus's first miracle, turning water into wine at a wedding feast in Cana of Galilee.
Description
Displayed in the great sacristy, this painting depicts Christ's first miracle at the wedding feast. Notable for including a self-portrait of the artist among the wedding guests.

title: Marcus Aurelius Relief Panels (South Side)
subtitle: c. AD 176–180 (reign of Marcus Aurelius); reused AD 315 · Marble relief panels
content:
Marcus Aurelius Relief Panels (South Side)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Antonine era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Marble relief panels
Date: c. AD 176–180 (reign of Marcus Aurelius); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
Four rectangular panels on the south side of the attic, from the same Antonine monument. From left to right: a captured enemy chieftain led before the emperor, another scene of prisoners presented, the emperor speaking to the troops (adlocutio), and the emperor sacrificing a pig, sheep, and bull (suovetaurilia). These panels exemplify the naturalistic, deeply carved Antonine relief style with rich spatial depth and individualized figures.

title: Marcus Aurelius Relief Panels (North Side)
subtitle: c. AD 176–180 (reign of Marcus Aurelius); reused AD 315 · Marble relief panels
content:
Marcus Aurelius Relief Panels (North Side)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Antonine era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Marble relief panels
Date: c. AD 176–180 (reign of Marcus Aurelius); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
Four rectangular panels flanking the inscription on the north (city-facing) side of the attic, taken from a lost triumphal monument commemorating Marcus Aurelius' wars against the Marcomanni and Sarmatians (AD 169–175). From left to right they depict: the emperor's adventus (return to Rome), his departure saluted by a personification of the Via Flaminia, a largitio (distribution of money to the people), and the interrogation of a German prisoner. The emperor's head was recarved to resemble Constantine; on the largitio panel, the figure of Commodus was erased following his damnatio memoriae.

title: Marble Doorcase
subtitle: 11th century · Marble carving
content:
Marble Doorcase
Artist: Giovanni di Venetia
Location: Santa Maria in Cosmedin, Rome
Medium: Marble carving
Date: 11th century
Source: self-research
Description
A signed marble doorcase featuring Classical motifs including birds, foliage, a blessing hand, and Evangelist symbols. One of the few signed works of medieval architectural sculpture in Rome.

title: Marble David
subtitle: Donatello · 1408-1416 · Marble
content:
Marble David
Wikipedia>)
Artist: Donatello
Location: Bargello, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: 1408-1416
Description
First large-scale nude sculpture since antiquity.

title: Magi Chapel
subtitle: Benozzo Gozzoli · c. 1459 · Fresco
content:
Magi Chapel
Wikipedia
Artist: Benozzo Gozzoli
Location: Palazzo Medici Riccardi, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 1459
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Adoration of the Magi - The visit of the three wise men (Magi) to the infant Jesus.
Description
A chapel in the Palazzo Medici Riccardi whose walls are almost entirely covered by a famous cycle of frescoes by Benozzo Gozzoli, painted around 1459 for the Medici family.
The chapel was built by Michelozzo di Bartolomeo between 1446 and 1449 and dedicated to the Holy Trinity. It comprises an almost square main room and, one step higher, an equally nearly square chancel, with the two separated from each other by two Corinthian pillars.
The frescoes feature the Angels in Adoration in the rectangular apse and the Journey of the Magi in the large hall. Each of the three large frescoes shows the procession of one of the Three Magi on their way to Bethlehem to see the Nativity of Jesus. Given the chapel's small size, entrance is limited to groups of up to 10 people at a time.

title: Madonna with Glass Eyes (Madonna degli Occhi di Vetro)
subtitle: Arnolfo di Cambio · c. 1300-1310 · Marble with glass inlay
content:
Madonna with Glass Eyes (Madonna degli Occhi di Vetro)
Artist: Arnolfo di Cambio
Location: Museo dell'Opera del Duomo, Florence
Medium: Marble with glass inlay
Date: c. 1300-1310
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary depicted with the infant Jesus.
Description
An original sculpture from the main portal of Florence Cathedral, depicting the Virgin Mary with Saints Reparata and Zanobi. Notable for the glass eyes that give the figure an unusually lifelike appearance. The use of glass inlay for the eyes was an innovative technique that enhanced the sculpture's expressiveness.

title: Madonna of the Stairs
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1491 · Marble relief
content:
Madonna of the Stairs
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Casa Buonarroti, Florence
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. 1491
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary nursing the Christ Child.
Description
An early relief sculpture by Michelangelo, created when he was about 16 years old. Notable for the extraordinary muscular back and right arm of the Christ Child, foreshadowing Michelangelo's later mastery of the human form.
The technique shows the influence of Donatello's schiacciato (very shallow relief), which Michelangelo studied during his time in the Medici garden. Despite its small size (55.5 x 40 cm), the composition feels monumental, with the Virgin's powerful, muscular arms and contemplative pose anticipating Michelangelo's mature style. Children play on stairs in the background—hence the name.

title: Madonna of the Magnificat
subtitle: Sandro Botticelli · c. 1481 · Tempera on panel
content:
Madonna of the Magnificat
Wikipedia
Artist: Sandro Botticelli
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Format: Tondo (circular)
Date: c. 1481
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Magnificat is the canticle of Mary found in Luke 1:46-55, her song of praise after the Annunciation: "My soul magnifies the Lord, and my spirit rejoices in God my Savior."
Description
Probably a wedding present or a gift for a birth of a child. The circular format (tondo) was popular for domestic devotional images. Changing size from 33 to 46 inches was typical at the time.

title: Madonna of Mercy between St Francis and St John the Baptist
subtitle: 15th century · Painting
content:
Madonna of Mercy between St Francis and St John the Baptist
Artist: Unknown (Umbrian school)
Location: Pantheon, Rome
Medium: Painting
Date: 15th century
Source: self-research
Description
Also known as the Madonna of the Railing, this 15th-century painting of the Umbrian school is located in the third chapel. It depicts the Madonna sheltering the faithful beneath her mantle, flanked by Saints Francis and John the Baptist.

title: Madonna Nicopeia Icon
subtitle: 10th-11th century (frame 14th century) · Tempera on wood with enamel frame
content:
Madonna Nicopeia Icon
Artist: Unknown Byzantine iconographer
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Tempera on wood with enamel frame
Date: 10th-11th century (frame 14th century)
Source: self-research
Description
A revered Byzantine icon of the Virgin and Child, originally from Constantinople, brought to Venice after the Fourth Crusade of 1204. The name "Nicopeia" means "bringer of victory" and was once carried into battle by Byzantine emperors. Now displayed in the Cappella della Madonna Nicopeia on the north side of the transept.

title: Madonna del Sasso
subtitle: Lorenzetto · c. 1524 · Marble sculpture
content:
Madonna del Sasso
Artist: Lorenzetto
Location: Pantheon, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: c. 1524
Source: self-research
Description
A marble statue of the Virgin and Child placed above Raphael's tomb in the third aedicule. Named "Madonna of the Rock" because Mary rests one foot on a boulder. Lorenzetto, a pupil of Raphael, created the sculpture as a close replica of the Venus Felix in the Vatican Museum, modeling the drapery after a version of the Aphrodite of Melos.

title: Madonna and Child with St. Nicholas and St. Lawrence
subtitle: Cima da Conegliano · Early 16th century · Oil on panel
content:
Madonna and Child with St. Nicholas and St. Lawrence
Artist: Cima da Conegliano
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: Early 16th century
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
Features Cima's characteristic atmospheric handling with a bright palette. His tranquil, luminous style shows the influence of both Bellini and Antonello da Messina.

title: Madonna, Child and St. John the Baptist
subtitle: Vittore Carpaccio · Early period · Oil on panel
content:
Madonna, Child and St. John the Baptist
Artist: Vittore Carpaccio
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: Early period
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
A recently confirmed early work by Carpaccio, demonstrating his developing style before the major cycles for which he became famous.

title: The Madonna and Child with Saints
subtitle: Domenico Veneziano · c. 1445–1447 · Tempera on panel
content:
The Madonna and Child with Saints
Wikipedia
Artist: Domenico Veneziano
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1445–1447
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus, representing the Incarnation of God.
Description
Also known as the St. Lucy Altarpiece. A masterpiece of early Renaissance painting.

title: Madonna and Child with Saint Anne (Dei Palafrenieri)
subtitle: Caravaggio · 1605–1606 · Oil on canvas
content:
Madonna and Child with Saint Anne (Dei Palafrenieri)
Wikipedia)
Artist: Caravaggio
Location: Galleria Borghese, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1605–1606
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - Virgin Mary with infant Jesus.
Description
Painted for the altar of the Papal Grooms in St. Peter's Basilica but quickly removed due to its unorthodox portrayal, including the nudity of the Christ child. Purchased by Cardinal Scipione Borghese after its rejection.

title: Madonna and Child with Angels
subtitle: Lorenzo Lotto · c. 1525 · Oil on panel
content:
Madonna and Child with Angels
Artist: Lorenzo Lotto
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1525
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
Spiritual, meditative figures set in a landscape. Lotto's distinctive psychological approach to religious subjects is evident in this work.

title: Madonna and Child
subtitle: Michele Giambono · Early 15th century · Tempera on panel
content:
Madonna and Child
Artist: Michele Giambono
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: Early 15th century
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
A work in the International Gothic style with a refined palette. Giambono designed the mosaics of the Birth of the Virgin and Presentation in the Temple.

title: Madonna and Child
subtitle: Dieric Bouts · Mid-15th century · Oil on panel
content:
Madonna and Child
Artist: Dieric Bouts
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: Mid-15th century
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
Features pearls and coral symbolizing the virgin birth and Christ's sacrifice. Demonstrates Flemish influence in the Venetian collection.

title: Madonna and Child
subtitle: Bartolomeo Vivarini · Mid-15th century · Tempera on panel
content:
Madonna and Child
Artist: Bartolomeo Vivarini
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: Mid-15th century
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus.
Description
One of two Madonna and Child paintings by Bartolomeo Vivarini in the collection, representing the transition from Late Gothic to Early Renaissance in Venice.

title: Lupanar Graffiti
subtitle: 1st century AD · Graffiti (scratched and painted inscriptions)
content:
Lupanar Graffiti
Wikipedia
Artist: Anonymous (multiple authors)
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Graffiti (scratched and painted inscriptions)
Date: 1st century AD
Source: self-research
Description
Over 150 graffiti inscriptions have been transcribed from Pompeii's most famous brothel. The texts include greetings, boasts, poems, death notices, and compliments in Latin, Greek, and native Oscan. The presence of graffiti served as one of the criteria for identifying the building as a brothel. These inscriptions provide insight into the multilingual nature of Roman Pompeii and the demographics of those who frequented such establishments.

title: Lupanar Frescoes
subtitle: 1st century AD · Fresco
content:
Lupanar Frescoes
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown Roman painters
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1st century AD
Source: self-research
Description
The Lupanar is the most famous ancient Roman brothel in Pompeii, known for the erotic paintings on its walls above each of the five doorways on the ground floor. These frescoes may have served as a menu of services or simply as decoration. Pompeii was closely associated with Venus, goddess of love.

title: Loggia Mosaics
subtitle: Filippo Rusuti · c. 1288–1297 · Mosaic
content:
Loggia Mosaics
Artist: Filippo Rusuti
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Mosaic
Date: c. 1288–1297
Source: self-research
Description
Mosaics decorating the upper loggia of the basilica's facade. The upper register shows Christ Blessing flanked by symbols of the four Evangelists; the lower register narrates the legend of the miraculous August snowfall that prompted the founding of the basilica by Pope Liberius. These 13th-century mosaics are now partially hidden behind the 18th-century facade by Ferdinando Fuga.

title: Lion of Saint Mark
subtitle: Medieval · Various (bronze, stone, mosaic)
content:
Lion of Saint Mark
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Various (bronze, stone, mosaic)
Date: Medieval
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Tetramorph - The winged lion is one of the four living creatures from the visions of Ezekiel and Revelation, traditionally associated with Saint Mark the Evangelist.
Description
The winged lion symbol of Saint Mark the Evangelist and the city of Venice. Appears prominently throughout the basilica, including a golden lion surmounting the pinnacle holding a Bible. Derived from the Tetramorph vision in Ezekiel and Revelation where Mark is represented as a lion.

title: Libyan Sibyl
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1511 · Fresco
content:
Libyan Sibyl
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1511
Description
One of five sibyls (pagan prophetesses) depicted on the Sistine Chapel ceiling, alternating with seven Old Testament prophets. The Libyan Sibyl is shown in a complex twisting pose, reaching for a large book. The light from the Separation of Light from Darkness falls onto the pages of the open book she holds.
The figure demonstrates Michelangelo's mastery of the human form, with powerful musculature visible beneath flowing drapery.

title: Liberation of Saint Peter
subtitle: Raphael · 1514 · Fresco
content:
Liberation of Saint Peter
Wikipedia)
Artist: Raphael
Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1514
Description
Peter is depicted as a portrait of Julius II. The fresco shows three scenes: the angel appearing to Peter in prison (center), the angel leading Peter past the sleeping guards (right), and the guards awakening to discover Peter's escape (left). Remarkable for its dramatic use of multiple light sources.

title: Legend of the True Cross
subtitle: Agnolo Gaddi · 1385–1387 · Fresco
content:
Legend of the True Cross
Wikipedia)
Artist: Agnolo Gaddi
Location: Santa Croce, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1385–1387
Description
Fresco cycle in the apse of Santa Croce. Agnolo Gaddi was the last major Florentine painter stylistically descended from Giotto.

title: Legend of Saint Ursula Cycle
subtitle: Vittore Carpaccio · 1490-1495 · Tempera on canvas
content:
Legend of Saint Ursula Cycle
Artist: Vittore Carpaccio
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Tempera on canvas
Date: 1490-1495
Source: self-research
Description
A cycle of nine large paintings commissioned by the Loredan family depicting the legend of Saint Ursula and her eleven thousand virgin martyrs. Notable for detailed depictions of architecture, nature, and contemporary Venetian life. Includes famous scenes such as The Dream of Saint Ursula.

title: Legend of Saint Ursula
subtitle: Vittore Carpaccio · 1490–1495 · Oil on canvas
content:
Legend of Saint Ursula
Wikipedia
Artist: Vittore Carpaccio
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1490–1495
Description
Series of large wall paintings about the legend of Saint Ursula, a British princess who, along with 11,000 virgin companions, was martyred by the Huns at Cologne. The series shows Carpaccio's command of perspective and precise attention to architectural detail.

title: Laurentian Library
subtitle: 1525-1571 · Architecture
content:
Laurentian Library
Wikipedia
Architect: Michelangelo
Location: Basilica of San Lorenzo, Florence
Medium: Architecture
Date: 1525-1571
Source: self-research
Description
A historic library in Florence, containing more than 11,000 manuscripts and 4,500 early printed books. Built in a cloister of the Medicean Basilica di San Lorenzo under the patronage of the Medici pope Clement VII, the library was built to emphasize that the Medici were no longer just merchants but members of intelligent and ecclesiastical society.
The library building is renowned for its architecture designed by Michelangelo and is an example of Mannerism. The vestibule features a revolutionary staircase with three flights that pour down like lava, creating a dramatic entrance to the reading room. The architectural elements—columns, pilasters, and brackets—are treated in unconventional ways that anticipate Baroque architecture.

title: Last Supper with the Tree of Life
subtitle: Taddeo Gaddi · c. 1355–1360 · Fresco
content:
Last Supper with the Tree of Life
Artist: Taddeo Gaddi
Location: Santa Croce, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 1355–1360
Biblical Context
Last Supper - Jesus's final meal with his twelve disciples before his crucifixion, during which he instituted the Eucharist (Matthew 26:17-30).
Description
Frescoes in the Refectory of Santa Croce. Notable for placing Judas on "our" side of the table, a convention that continued until Leonardo's Last Supper.

title: The Last Supper
subtitle: Leonardo da Vinci · c. 1495–1498 · Tempera on gesso, pitch and mastic
content:
The Last Supper
Wikipedia)
Artist: Leonardo da Vinci
Location: Santa Maria delle Grazie, Milan
Medium: Tempera on gesso, pitch and mastic
Date: c. 1495–1498
Biblical Context
Last Supper - Jesus's final meal with his twelve disciples before his crucifixion, during which he instituted the Eucharist and announced that one of them would betray him.
Gospel References
Leonardo synthesized multiple Gospel accounts:
Gospel of St. John (13:26): Christ identified the betrayer by handing him a piece of bread dipped in wine
Gospels of Matthew and Mark: Christ indicated, "He who dippeth with me in the dish"
Luke: "He whose hand is with me on the table"
Matthew, Mark and Luke: "Verily I say unto you, that one of you shall betray me. And they were exceeding sorrowful, and began every one to say unto him, Lord, is it I"
Description
Leonardo's masterpiece depicting the moment Jesus announces that one of his disciples will betray him.
Composition
Placed Judas among the loyal disciples (unlike earlier depictions)
Judas is the only apostle who need not protest
Judas is the only one who reaches for food
Judas is the only one who recoils from Christ
Judas is the only one whose face is not in the light
Christ turns from Judas
Condition
Poor condition is due to Leonardo's experimental painting technique:
In 1566 it was already in a bad state
Repainted twice in the eighteenth century
Suffered from Napoleonic soldiers and monks
Repainted again in the nineteenth century
The building was bombed by Allied forces in WWII
Related
Study of Composition of Last Supper - Preparatory drawing at Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice

title: The Last Supper
subtitle: Domenico Ghirlandaio · 1486 · Fresco
content:
The Last Supper
Wikipedia)
Artist: Domenico Ghirlandaio
Location: San Marco, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1486
Biblical Context
Last Supper - Jesus's final meal with his twelve disciples before his crucifixion, during which he instituted the Eucharist (Matthew 26:17-30, Mark 14:12-26, Luke 22:7-38, John 13:1-17:26).
Description
Fresco by Ghirlandaio at San Marco, Florence.

title: Last Supper
subtitle: El Greco · 1568 · Panel painting
content:
Last Supper
Wikipedia)
Artist: El Greco
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Panel painting
Date: 1568
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Last Supper - The final meal Jesus shared with his apostles before his Crucifixion, during which he instituted the Eucharist.
Description
An early work by El Greco from his Venetian period, before he developed the more elongated and dramatic style for which he became famous. The painting shows the influence of Venetian masters during his formative years.

title: Last Supper
subtitle: Andrea del Castagno · 1445–1450 · Fresco
content:
Last Supper
Wikipedia)
Artist: Andrea del Castagno
Location: Sant'Apollonia, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1445–1450
Biblical Context
Last Supper - Jesus's final meal with his twelve disciples before his crucifixion, during which he instituted the Eucharist (Matthew 26:17-30, Mark 14:12-26, Luke 22:7-38, John 13:1-17:26).
Description
Considered the first "Last Supper" of the Renaissance in Florence, located in the refectory of the former Benedictine convent of Sant'Apollonia. Judas is depicted sitting separately on the near side of the table, unlike all the other apostles.
The fresco is notable for its perspective illusion, as if the scene was happening in a small room and the viewer was observing from outside. The highly detailed marble walls hearken back to Roman "First Style" wall paintings. Saint John's posture of innocent slumber neatly contrasts with Judas's tense, upright pose.
The fresco was hidden behind plaster for over a century because the convent was cloistered. Vasari did not know of its existence. It may have influenced Leonardo da Vinci's later version, painted about 50 years later.

title: The Last Judgement (Vasari and Zuccari)
subtitle: Giorgio Vasari · 1572-1579 · Fresco
content:
The Last Judgement (Vasari and Zuccari)
Wikipedia)
Artist: Giorgio Vasari and Federico Zuccari
Location: Florence Cathedral, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1572-1579
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Last Judgement - The final and eternal judgment by God of all humanity at the end of time.
Description
A monumental fresco covering the interior of Brunelleschi's dome. Initially commissioned by Grand Duke Cosimo I de' Medici, it was begun by Giorgio Vasari in 1572 and completed after his death by Federico Zuccari in 1579. The subject was inspired by Michelangelo's work on the Sistine Chapel ceiling. It was extensively restored between 1989 and 1994.

title: Last Judgement
subtitle: Pietro Cavallini · c. 1289–1293 · Fresco
content:
Last Judgement
Artist: Pietro Cavallini
Location: Santa Cecilia in Trastevere, Rome
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 1289–1293
Biblical Context
Last Judgement - The final and eternal judgment by God of all humanity at the end of time (Matthew 25:31-46, Revelation 20:11-15).
Description
Notable for Cavallini's innovative use of light source in his painting, a significant advancement in the Duecento period.

title: Lapis Niger
subtitle: 7th-6th century BC
content:
Lapis Niger
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Ancient Shrine
Date: 7th-6th century BC
Source: self-research
Description
An ancient shrine marked by black marble paving stones, among the oldest monuments in the Forum. The site contains one of the oldest known Latin inscriptions (Cippus of the Lapis Niger), dating to the 6th or 5th century BC. The shrine was considered sacred even in ancient times, and its original purpose was obscure even to the Romans.

title: Laocoön and His Sons
subtitle: Agesander of Rhodes · c. 40-30 BC (or possibly later Roman copy of earlier Greek bronze) · Marble
content:
Laocoön and His Sons
Wikipedia
Artist: Agesander of Rhodes, Athenodoros, and Polydorus
Location: Vatican Museums, Vatican City
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 40-30 BC (or possibly later Roman copy of earlier Greek bronze)
Source: Self-researched
Description
One of the most famous ancient sculptures, excavated in Rome in 1506 and displayed in the Vatican since then. The nearly life-sized group (over 2m high) depicts the Trojan priest Laocoön and his sons Antiphantes and Thymbraeus being attacked by sea serpents. Praised by Pliny the Elder as superior to any work of painting or sculpture.

title: Landscape of the Arno Valley
subtitle: Leonardo da Vinci · August 5, 1473 · Pen and ink on paper
content:
Landscape of the Arno Valley
Artist: Leonardo da Vinci
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Pen and ink on paper
Date: August 5, 1473
Description
One of the earliest dated works by Leonardo, this landscape drawing shows the Arno Valley near Florence. It demonstrates Leonardo's early interest in capturing natural phenomena and atmospheric perspective.

title: Lamentation over the Dead Christ
subtitle: Pietro Perugino · 1495 · Oil on panel
content:
Lamentation over the Dead Christ
Wikipedia)
Artist: Pietro Perugino
Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: 1495
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Lamentation (Pietà) - The mourning over Christ's body after the Crucifixion, before the Entombment.
Description
A large and emotionally restrained depiction of the lamentation, showing the dead Christ mourned by the Virgin Mary, Saint John the Evangelist, Mary Magdalene, and other figures. Perugino's characteristic grace and soft, luminous coloring are evident, with a serene Umbrian landscape visible in the background. Displayed in the Sala di Apollo.

title: The Foreshortened Christ (Lamentation of Christ)
subtitle: Andrea Mantegna · c. 1480 · Tempera on canvas
content:
The Foreshortened Christ (Lamentation of Christ)
Wikipedia)
Artist: Andrea Mantegna
Location: Pinacoteca di Brera, Milan
Medium: Tempera on canvas
Date: c. 1480
Biblical Context
Lamentation - The mourning over Christ's body after the Crucifixion and before his burial. While not directly described in scripture, it is derived from the burial accounts in the Gospels (Matthew 27:57-61, Mark 15:42-47, Luke 23:50-56, John 19:38-42).
Description
Famous for its dramatic use of foreshortening, showing Christ's body from the feet with the wounds in his feet prominently visible.

title: La velata
subtitle: Raphael · c. 1515-1516 · Oil on canvas
content:
La velata
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Pitti Gallery, Florence
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1515-1516
Description
"The Veiled Woman" - The rich color in the painting suggests Raphael's interest in the colorism of Venice. The identity of the sitter is unknown, though she may be the same woman who appears in the Sistine Madonna and is traditionally identified as Raphael's mistress, known as "La Fornarina."

title: La donna gravida
subtitle: Raphael · c. 1505–1506 · Oil on panel
content:
La donna gravida
Wikipedia
Artist: Raphael
Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: c. 1505–1506
Source: self-research
Description
A portrait of a pregnant woman, painted during Raphael's Florentine period. The sitter gazes directly at the viewer with a calm, dignified expression, one hand resting on her belly. The identity of the woman is unknown. The painting shows the influence of Leonardo da Vinci in its soft modeling and atmospheric quality, and is notable for its rare subject of pregnancy in Renaissance portraiture.

title: La Bella
subtitle: Titian · c. 1536 · Oil on canvas
content:
La Bella
Wikipedia
Artist: Titian
Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1536
Source: self-research
Description
A portrait of an unknown woman in a sumptuous blue dress, exemplifying the Renaissance ideal of female beauty. The sitter's identity is debated, though she may be the same model as Titian's Venus of Urbino. The work is documented in a 1536 letter from the Duke of Urbino describing "that portrait of that woman in a blue dress." It hangs in the Sala di Venere.

title: Keystone Figures
subtitle: c. AD 312–315 · Marble relief
content:
Keystone Figures
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Constantinian era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. AD 312–315
Source: self-research
Description
The keystones of the three arches feature carved busts or figures. The central arch keystones show Sol (the sun god) on the east side and Luna (the moon goddess) on the west, representing the cosmic order under Constantine's rule. The lateral arch keystones depict Mars, Roma, and other deities or personifications.

title: Justice Between the Archangels Michael and Gabriel
subtitle: Jacobello del Fiore · 1421 · Tempera on panel
content:
Justice Between the Archangels Michael and Gabriel
Artist: Jacobello del Fiore
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: 1421
Description
A triptych depicting the personification of Justice flanked by the Archangels Michael and Gabriel.

title: Juno Showering Gifts on Venice
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · 1553-1554 · Oil on canvas (ceiling)
content:
Juno Showering Gifts on Venice
Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas (ceiling)
Date: 1553-1554
Source: self-research
Description
Located in the Council of Ten Room, this ceiling painting shows the goddess Juno bestowing gifts upon the personification of Venice, symbolizing the city's prosperity and divine favor.

title: Judith with the Head of Holofernes
subtitle: Cristofano Allori · 1613 · Oil on canvas
content:
Judith with the Head of Holofernes
Artist: Cristofano Allori
Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1613
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Judith and Holofernes - The story of the Jewish widow Judith who saves her people by beheading the Assyrian general Holofernes.
Description
One of the most celebrated paintings of the Florentine Seicento, depicting Judith holding the severed head of Holofernes while her maidservant waits with a bag. Allori reportedly used his own face as the model for Holofernes, his mistress for Judith, and her mother for the maidservant, lending the painting an intensely personal subtext. Multiple versions exist, with this being the finest.

title: Judith and Holofernes
subtitle: Donatello · c. 1457–1464 · Bronze
content:
Judith and Holofernes
Wikipedia)
Artist: Donatello
Location: Palazzo Vecchio, Florence
Medium: Bronze
Date: c. 1457–1464
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Judith and Holofernes - Judith, a beautiful Jewish widow, saves her city from the Assyrian general Holofernes by entering his camp, gaining his trust, and then beheading him while he slept drunk. The story represents the triumph of virtue over tyranny and of the weak over the powerful.
Description
Bronze sculpture by Donatello depicting the biblical heroine Judith beheading the Assyrian general Holofernes. Created toward the end of Donatello's career, it is located in the Sala dei Gigli (Hall of Lilies). A copy stands in one of the sculpture's original positions in the Piazza della Signoria.

title: Joy of Prairies and Gardens
subtitle: c. 1735-1762 · Marble sculpture
content:
Joy of Prairies and Gardens
Artist: Bartolomeo Pincellotti
Location: Trevi Fountain, Rome
Medium: Marble sculpture
Date: c. 1735-1762
Source: self-research
Description
The fourth attic-level statue, this figure is adorned with flowers, representing the flourishing of meadows and gardens nourished by the aqueduct's waters.

title: Jesus giving the Keys to St. Peter
subtitle: Lorenzo Veneziano · 1370 · Tempera on panel
content:
Jesus giving the Keys to St. Peter
Artist: Lorenzo Veneziano
Location: Museo Correr, Venice
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: 1370
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Delivery of the Keys - Jesus giving Peter the keys to the kingdom of heaven.
Description
A monumental composition with marble throne. Lorenzo Veneziano was the first Venetian painter to move away from Byzantine models toward the Gothic style.

title: Jacob's Return to Canaan
subtitle: Jacopo Bassano · c. 1580 · Oil on canvas
content:
Jacob's Return to Canaan
Artist: Jacopo Bassano
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1580
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Jacob - The patriarch Jacob, later named Israel, returning to Canaan with his family and flocks after years in exile. Genesis 31-33.
Description
Located in the Sala dell'Anticollegio alongside works by Tintoretto and Veronese. Depicts the biblical patriarch Jacob returning to Canaan with his family and flocks. Bassano's characteristic treatment of pastoral and rural scenes is evident in this work.

title: Isaiah
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1508-1509 · Fresco
content:
Isaiah
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1508-1509
Description
The first prophet to be painted on the Sistine Chapel ceiling. Isaiah turns away from the Flood, which is above and to his left, as if in answer to God's promise: "For to Me this is like the days of Noah, when I swore that the waters of Noah would never again cover the earth. So I have sworn that I will not be angry with you or rebuke you." (Isaiah 54:9)
One of seven Old Testament prophets depicted on the ceiling, alternating with five sibyls (pagan prophetesses).

title: Il Paradiso
subtitle: Tintoretto · 1588-1592 · Oil on canvas
content:
Il Paradiso
Wikipedia
Artist: Tintoretto
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1588-1592
Source: self-research
Description
A massive painting (22 x 9 metres) dominating the main hall of the Doge's Palace, one of the largest paintings on canvas in the world. The composition features around 500 figures in a heavenly scene. The light emanating from Christ descends along the central axis directly to the doge's throne, symbolizing that the Doge receives his authority from on high.

title: House of the Vettii Frescoes
subtitle: After 62 AD · Fresco
content:
House of the Vettii Frescoes

Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Fresco
Date: After 62 AD
Source: self-research
Description
A domus owned by two successful freedmen, Aulus Vettius Conviva and Aulus Vettius Restitutus. Contains twelve mythological scenes across four cubiculums and one triclinium, completed after the earthquake of 62 AD in the Fourth Style. The entrance features a famous fresco of Priapus. Reopened to tourists in 2023 after two decades of restoration.

title: House of the Vestals
subtitle: Roman Republic to Late Empire
content:
House of the Vestals
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Residence
Date: Roman Republic to Late Empire
Source: self-research
Description
The residence of the Vestal Virgins, located behind the circular Temple of Vesta at the eastern edge of the Roman Forum. The complex includes a large central courtyard (atrium) surrounded by a two-story colonnade, with statues of senior Vestals lining the court. The Vestals were among the most powerful women in Rome, enjoying privileges denied to other women.

title: House of the Tragic Poet
subtitle: 2nd century BC · Mosaic, fresco
content:
House of the Tragic Poet

Source: self-research
Description
A Roman house famous for its elaborate mosaic floors and frescoes depicting scenes from Greek mythology. Most famous for the "Cave Canem" (Beware of the Dog) mosaic in the vestibule, showing a chained dog with a warning to visitors. The house features scenes from the Iliad and other classical subjects.

title: House of the Faun
subtitle: 2nd century BC (Samnite period) · Architecture, mosaics, sculpture

House of the Faun
