Artist: Various Roman craftsmen
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Architecture, mosaics, sculpture
Date: 2nd century BC (Samnite period)
Source: self-research
Description
A grand Hellenistic residence that is one of the most luxurious aristocratic houses from the Roman Republic. Named for its famous bronze Dancing Faun statue in the impluvium. The house contained numerous masterpieces including the Alexander Mosaic, Nilotic scenes, and theatrical masks. It reflects this period better than most archaeological evidence found even in Rome itself.

Illuminated book of hours created for Gian Galeazzo Visconti, the first Duke of Milan.

Horses of Saint Mark

A group of four bronze horses that originally formed part of a quadriga monument. Brought to Venice from Constantinople after the Fourth Crusade in 1204. The originals are now in the basilica museum, with replicas on the facade. Also known as the Triumphal Quadriga.

One of three ceiling tondi by Veronese in the library's main hall, depicting an enthroned male figure (Honour) being adored by the Virtues. Part of a decorative programme of 21 ceiling paintings selected by Sansovino and Titian.

title: Hercules Slaying Antaeus

Hercules Slaying Antaeus

Depicts the mythological battle between Hercules and the giant Antaeus, who gained strength from contact with the earth. Hercules defeats him by lifting him off the ground.

Hercules and the Hydra

First large-scale Renaissance works about mythology. Depicts Hercules in battle with the Lernaean Hydra, one of his twelve labors.

Hercules and Cacus

Hercules and Antaeus (Bronze)

title: Hadrianic Tondi (North Side: Lion Hunt and Sacrifice to Hercules)
subtitle: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315 · White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter, framed in porphyry
content:
Hadrianic Tondi (North Side: Lion Hunt and Sacrifice to Hercules)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Hadrianic era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter, framed in porphyry
Date: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
The right pair of roundels on the north side depicts a dramatic lion hunt (left tondo) and a sacrifice to Hercules (right tondo). As with all the Hadrianic tondi, the emperor's head was recarved — in hunting scenes to resemble Constantine, and in sacrifice scenes to resemble Licinius or Constantius I. The high-relief carving shows the classical Hadrianic style with carefully modeled anatomy and deep undercutting.

title: Hadrianic Tondi (South Side: Departure for the Hunt and Sacrifice to Silvanus)
subtitle: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315 · White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter
content:
Hadrianic Tondi (South Side: Departure for the Hunt and Sacrifice to Silvanus)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Hadrianic era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter
Date: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
The left pair of roundels on the south side shows the departure for the hunt, with attendants and horses preparing for the chase, and a sacrifice to Silvanus, the Roman god of woods and wild nature. The tondi demonstrate the Hadrianic preference for depicting emperors in leisure activities alongside religious devotion.

title: Hadrianic Tondi (North Side: Boar Hunt and Sacrifice to Apollo)
subtitle: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315 · White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter, framed in porphyry
content:
Hadrianic Tondi (North Side: Boar Hunt and Sacrifice to Apollo)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Hadrianic era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter, framed in porphyry
Date: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
Two of eight circular relief medallions (tondi) originally from a lost monument to Emperor Hadrian. The left tondo depicts a boar hunt with Hadrian on horseback (recarved to resemble Constantine) and the figure of Antinous visible at top left. The right tondo shows a sacrifice to Apollo. The tondi are among the finest examples of Hadrianic classicizing sculpture, characterized by idealized figures and naturalistic proportions.

title: Hadrianic Tondi (South Side: Bear Hunt and Sacrifice to Diana)
subtitle: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315 · White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter
content:
Hadrianic Tondi (South Side: Bear Hunt and Sacrifice to Diana)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Hadrianic era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: White Luna marble relief, c. 2.4m diameter
Date: c. AD 117–138 (reign of Hadrian); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
The right pair on the south side depicts a bear hunt (left tondo) and a sacrifice to Diana, the goddess of the hunt (right tondo). The eight tondi collectively present a unified program of imperial virtus (courage in the hunt) paired with pietas (devotion through sacrifice), a theme recontextualized for Constantine.

title: Great Trajanic Frieze
subtitle: c. AD 107–117 (reign of Trajan); reused AD 315 · Marble relief, c. 3m high
content:
Great Trajanic Frieze
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Trajanic era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Marble relief, c. 3m high
Date: c. AD 107–117 (reign of Trajan); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
Four large relief panels from a monumental frieze celebrating Trajan's Dacian Wars, likely removed from the Basilica Ulpia in Trajan's Forum. Two panels are mounted on the east and west ends of the attic, and two more line the interior of the central passageway. The scenes depict the emperor in heroic combat — charging into battle on horseback as Dacian soldiers fall beneath him — and his triumph, flanked by Roma and Victory preparing to crown him. Trajan's head was recarved to resemble Constantine, reframing the Dacian victory as a Constantinian triumph. The frieze demonstrates the vigorous, dramatic Trajanic style with densely packed figures and dynamic movement.

title: Glory of Saint Aloysius Gonzaga
subtitle: Pierre Le Gros the Younger · 1697-1699 · Marble relief
content:
Glory of Saint Aloysius Gonzaga
Artist: Pierre Le Gros the Younger
Location: Sant'Ignazio, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: 1697-1699
Source: self-research
Description
A large marble high-relief altarpiece in the right transept chapel depicting St. Aloysius Gonzaga ascending to heaven with symbols of Penance and Purity above. The monumental altar was designed by Andrea Pozzo. Two cherub sculptures by Le Gros embody the saint's renunciation of worldly honors—one pushing away a globe, the other with a marquis's crown at his feet. The chapel contains a lapis lazuli urn with the saint's remains.

title: Glorification of Saint Ignatius
subtitle: Andrea Pozzo · 1691-1694 · Fresco
content:
Glorification of Saint Ignatius
Artist: Andrea Pozzo
Location: Sant'Ignazio, Rome
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1691-1694
Source: self-research
Description
A masterpiece of Baroque illusionism covering over 40 meters of the nave ceiling. The fresco depicts the apotheosis of St. Ignatius, with light emanating from God the Father to the Son, then to St. Ignatius, breaking into four rays leading to allegorical representations of the four continents. The quadratura technique creates the illusion of three-dimensional architecture extending infinitely into the heavens, visible from a marked spot on the nave floor.

title: The Genius of Victory

The Genius of Victory

Located in the south cupola of the west narthex, these mosaics depict the Creation story from Genesis. The designs were influenced by the Cotton Genesis, a 4th-5th century illuminated manuscript brought from Constantinople. The cycle continues with scenes of Noah, Abraham, Joseph, and Moses in adjacent cupolas.

Description
The second set of bronze doors Ghiberti created for the Baptistery, depicting Old Testament scenes in ten rectangular panels. Michelangelo reportedly said they were worthy of being the "Gates of Paradise." The original panels are now displayed in glass cases in the Museo dell'Opera del Duomo. Contains the first sensuous female nudes of the Renaissance.

title: Garden of the Fugitives

content:
Garden of the Fugitives
Wikipedia

Medium: Plaster casts of victims
Date: 79 AD (eruption) / 19th century (casts)
Source: self-research
Description
An archaeological site containing the plaster casts of 13 victims of the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD. The casts were made by pouring plaster into the cavities left in the volcanic ash where the victims' bodies had decomposed, preserving their final moments in haunting detail.

title: Funerary Monument of John Hawkwood
subtitle: Paolo Uccello · 1436 · Fresco
content:
Funerary Monument of John Hawkwood

Location: Florence Cathedral, Florence

Description
A painted equestrian monument commemorating the English condottiero John Hawkwood, who served Florence as a mercenary captain. The fresco is an important example of art commemorating a soldier-for-hire and is a seminal work in the development of perspective. Located on the left internal wall of the cathedral.

Funeral of St. Francis

Notable for its calm composition balanced with dramatic details, exemplifying Giotto's narrative mastery.

Madonna and Child (Frizzoni Madonna)

An innovative depiction featuring the Madonna in an unusual purple gown and pink mantle, departing from the traditional blue. Known as the Frizzoni Madonna.

title: Frari Triptych

content:
Frari Triptych

Location: Basilica di Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari, Venice

Uses oil that enabled Bellini to cast golden light onto Mary. A triptych altarpiece still in its original location in the sacristy of the Frari.

title: Fra Mauro Map
subtitle: Fra Mauro · c. 1450 · Ink on parchment
content:
Fra Mauro Map
Wikipedia
Artist: Fra Mauro
Location: Biblioteca Marciana, Venice
Medium: Ink on parchment
Date: c. 1450
Source: self-research
Description
Considered the greatest memorial of medieval cartography, this circular world map (planisphere) measures over two by two meters. It includes Asia, the Indian Ocean, Africa, Europe, and the Atlantic, with south oriented at the top. Contains hundreds of detailed illustrations and more than 3000 descriptive texts.

title: Four Crowned Martyrs
subtitle: Nanni di Banco · c. 1409–1417 · Marble
content:
Four Crowned Martyrs
Wikipedia)
Artist: Nanni di Banco
Location: Orsanmichele, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 1409–1417
Description
Part of the sculptural program at Orsanmichele. Commissioned by the guild of stone and wood workers (Arte dei Maestri di Pietra e Legname), this sculptural group shows four Early Christian sculptors—Claudius, Castorius, Symphorian, and Nicostratus—who, according to legend, refused to carve a pagan idol for Emperor Diocletian and were martyred.
The work is remarkable for its classical Roman influence and innovative group composition within a single niche. The four figures engage in conversation, their drapery and poses recalling ancient Roman senatorial statues. This classical reference was particularly appropriate given that the martyrs were sculptors, connecting the guild members to an ancient artistic lineage.

title: Fontane di Piazza Farnese
subtitle: Original: 3rd century AD; Fountain conversion: 16th century · Granite
content:
Fontane di Piazza Farnese

Current Location: Piazza Farnese, Rome
Medium: Granite
Date: Original: 3rd century AD; Fountain conversion: 16th century
Source: self-research
Description
Two identical decorative fountains in Piazza Farnese, Rome, incorporating large granite tubs originally from the frigidarium of the Baths of Caracalla. The basins were taken from the Baths and placed in the piazza during the 16th century.

A marble sculpture depicting four figures: the dead body of Jesus Christ newly taken down from the Cross, Nicodemus (said to be Michelangelo's self-portrait), Mary Magdalene, and the Virgin Mary. title: The Flood
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1508-1509 · Fresco
content:
The Flood

Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1508-1509
Biblical Context
Story of Noah - The great flood sent by God to cleanse the earth of wickedness (Genesis 6-9).

Completed in 29 days. The scene shows the devastating flood waters rising as people desperately seek safety. The father carries the body of his drowned son—a powerful image of loss and divine judgment. One of the central narrative panels on the Sistine Chapel ceiling.

Fertility of Crops

An attic-level allegorical statue depicting the fertility of crops. The figure holds ears of wheat, symbolizing the agricultural prosperity enabled by the aqueduct's waters.

title: The Feast in the House of Levi
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · 1573 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Feast in the House of Levi

Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1573
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Last Supper - Jesus's final meal with his apostles before his crucifixion (the original intended subject).
Description
One of the largest canvases of the 16th century (555 x 1,309 cm). Originally painted as a Last Supper for a Dominican friary, Veronese's irreverent interpretation led to an investigation by the Inquisition. Rather than make changes, he simply renamed the painting. A masterpiece of Venetian colorism.

title: Farnese Hercules
subtitle: Glykon · Early 3rd century AD (copy of 4th century BC Greek bronze) · Marble
content:
Farnese Hercules
Wikipedia
Artist: Glykon (signed), after Lysippos (original Greek sculptor)
Original Location: Baths of Caracalla, Rome
Current Location: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Naples
Medium: Marble
Date: Early 3rd century AD (copy of 4th century BC Greek bronze)
Source: self-research
Mythological Context
The sculpture depicts Hercules after completing his twelve labors, exhausted but victorious. He leans wearily on his club, which is draped with the skin of the Nemean Lion (his first labor). Behind his back, he holds the golden apples of the Hesperides, obtained during his eleventh labor.
Description
A heroically-scaled statue depicting Hercules at rest, leaning on his gnarled club draped with the Nemean lion's skin, holding the golden apples of the Hesperides behind his back. One of the most famous sculptures of antiquity, it has fixed the image of the mythic hero in European imagination. Recovered from the frigidarium of the Baths in 1546.

title: Farnese Bull
subtitle: Roman copy of 2nd century BC original · Marble
content:
Farnese Bull
Wikipedia
Artist: After Apollonius of Tralles and Tauriscus (original Hellenistic sculptors)
Original Location: Baths of Caracalla, Rome
Current Location: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Naples
Medium: Marble
Date: Roman copy of 2nd century BC original
Source: self-research
Mythological Context
The sculpture depicts the myth of Dirce, queen of Thebes, being tied to a wild bull by the twins Amphion and Zethus. Dirce had cruelly mistreated their mother Antiope, and the brothers punished her by binding her to the bull's horns to be dragged to death.
Description
The largest single sculpture recovered from antiquity. This massive Roman elaborated copy of a Hellenistic sculpture depicts the myth of Dirce being tied to a wild bull by Amphion and Zethus as punishment for mistreating their mother Antiope. Excavated from the gymnasium of the Baths in 1546.

title: Fall of Simon Magus
subtitle: Pompeo Batoni · 1746-1755 · Oil on canvas
content:
Fall of Simon Magus

Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1746-1755
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Simon Magus - The apocryphal tradition of Simon Magus attempting to fly before Emperor Nero in Rome, only to be struck down by the prayers of Saints Peter and Paul.
Description
A monumental late Baroque painting originally intended as the basis for a mosaic altarpiece in St. Peter's Basilica. The work depicts the dramatic fall of the magician Simon Magus as he attempts to fly before the Roman Emperor Nero, struck down by the prayers of Saints Peter and Paul. It was removed from St. Peter's in 1757 and transferred to Santa Maria degli Angeli.

title: Fall of Adam and Eve and Expulsion
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1509-1510 · Fresco
content:
Fall of Adam and Eve and Expulsion
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1509-1510
Biblical Context
Expulsion from Paradise - Adam and Eve banished from the Garden of Eden after eating the forbidden fruit (Genesis 3).
Description
Completed in 13 days. Previously the Temptation and Expulsion had been depicted separately, but Michelangelo united them in the same fresco. On the left, Adam and Eve reach for the forbidden fruit offered by the serpent (depicted with a woman's torso); on the right, an angel drives them from Paradise. The contrast between their idealized bodies before the Fall and their aged, shamed forms after is striking.

title: Ezekiel's Vision
subtitle: Raphael · c. 1518 · Oil on panel
content:
Ezekiel's Vision

Location: Palazzo Pitti, Florence

Date: c. 1518
Source: self-research

Book of Ezekiel - The prophet Ezekiel's vision of God enthroned in majesty, borne by four living creatures symbolizing the four Evangelists.
Description
A small but powerfully composed painting depicting the prophet Ezekiel's vision of God in majesty, borne aloft by angels and the four symbols of the Evangelists. Despite its diminutive size (about 40 x 30 cm), the painting achieves monumental grandeur. It reflects the influence of Michelangelo's Sistine ceiling in its muscular figures and dynamic composition.

title: The Expulsion of Heliodorus from the Temple
subtitle: Raphael · 1511-1512 · Fresco
content:
The Expulsion of Heliodorus from the Temple

Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican

Description
Depicts the biblical story from 2 Maccabees in which Heliodorus, sent to seize the treasure of the Temple of Jerusalem, is driven out by divine intervention. The fresco was commissioned to assert papal authority over the Church's temporal possessions.

title: Erotic Art in Pompeii and Herculaneum
subtitle: 1st century BC - 1st century AD · Frescoes, sculpture, household items
content:
Erotic Art in Pompeii and Herculaneum
Wikipedia
Artist: Various Roman artists
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Frescoes, sculpture, household items
Date: 1st century BC - 1st century AD
Source: self-research
Description
The excavations of Pompeii and Herculaneum revealed cities rich in erotic artifacts including statues, frescoes, and household items decorated with sexual themes. The ubiquity of such imagery indicates that Roman attitudes toward sexual iconography were more relaxed than in modern Western culture. Much erotic art was also associated with fertility and religious practices related to Venus, the divine protector of Pompeii.

title: The Doni Tondo
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1506 · Tempera on panel
content:
The Doni Tondo
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence

Biblical Context
Madonna and Child - The Virgin Mary with the infant Jesus, here depicted as the Holy Family with St. Joseph.

The only preserved panel painting of Michelangelo. Also known as "The Dono Madonna" or "Holy Family with St. John the Baptist," this tondo (circular painting) was commissioned by the wealthy Florentine merchant Agnolo Doni. The unusual poses and vibrant colors influenced later Mannerist painters.

Dome of Florence Cathedral
Wikipedia

Location: Florence Cathedral, Florence

Revolutionary dome designed by Brunelleschi. Exactly half as wide as it is tall. The dome consists of an inner and outer shell.

title: Doge Giovanni Mocenigo

content:
Doge Giovanni Mocenigo
Wikipedia
Artist: Gentile Bellini
Location: Museo Correr, Venice

Date: c. 1478–1485
Description
Portrait of the Doge Giovanni Mocenigo. Gentile Bellini was the official portrait artist for the Doges of Venice from 1474.

title: Disputa
subtitle: Raphael · 1509-1510 · Fresco
content:
Disputa
Wikipedia

Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1509-1510

Holy Trinity - The theological doctrine of one God in three persons: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.
Description
Also known as the "Disputation of the Holy Sacrament," this fresco depicts the Church's triumph over heresy. The composition is organized in two zones: the heavenly realm above with Christ, Mary, John the Baptist, and the saints, and the earthly realm below with theologians debating the Eucharist.

Pentecost - The descent of the Holy Spirit upon the apostles fifty days after Easter, enabling them to speak in tongues (Acts 2:1-13).

Located on the left wall of the Chapel of the Crucifixion, this late 18th-century painting depicts the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the Apostles at Pentecost.

Deposition from the Cross - The removal of Christ's body from the cross after the Crucifixion, as described in the Gospels (Matthew 27:57-59, Mark 15:42-46, Luke 23:50-53, John 19:38-40).

Also known as the Santa Trinita Altarpiece. Notable for its new naturalism and harmony of figures and landscape.

Delivery of the Keys - Christ delivering the keys of the Church to Saint Peter, establishing Peter's authority. (Matthew 16:18-19)

A large altarpiece depicting Christ delivering the keys of the Church to Saint Peter, displayed in the Chapel of St. Peter. Muziano was one of the most prominent painters active in Rome in the mid-to-late sixteenth century.

Delivery of the Keys

Delivery of the Keys - The moment when Christ gives the keys of heaven to Saint Peter, establishing Peter's authority as the first Pope. Notable for Perugino's characteristic breadth and distance of spatial backgrounds.

David and Goliath - Young David defeats the giant Philistine warrior Goliath with a sling and stone (1 Samuel 17).

A haunting depiction of the young David holding the severed head of Goliath. The head of Goliath is believed to be a self-portrait of Caravaggio, painted during his final years while fleeing a murder charge.

title: David

David

David, the young shepherd who slew the giant Goliath with a stone from his sling, as told in 1 Samuel 17. This victory made him a hero of Israel and he later became king.

Bronze sculpture depicting David as a young man, with leather cloth and a smiling expression instead of the uncertain expression seen in earlier depictions.

title: David
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1501-1504 · Marble
content:
David
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Galleria dell'Accademia, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: 1501-1504
Source: my-study, self-research
Biblical Context
David and Goliath - The young David defeats the giant Philistine warrior Goliath with a sling and stone.
Description
The commission for Florence cathedral was originally assigned to Agostino di Duccio with a design by Donatello. When Donatello died, the stone was assigned to Michelangelo. The stone was tall but shallow and some work from Agostino had been done already.
The statue was designed to be placed on the Florence cathedral's buttress pedestals, on which the boy could look out over the city, gazing to the north. The statue was ultimately placed in front of Palazzo dei Priori (now Palazzo Vecchio).
The left arm and hand were damaged in 1527 and preserved by Vasari and Francesco Salviati. The original now stands in the Galleria dell'Accademia, while a replica stands in its original location in Piazza della Signoria.

title: David

David

Source: self-research

David and Goliath - Young David defeats the giant Philistine warrior Goliath with a sling and stone (1 Samuel 17).
Description
A life-size marble sculpture commissioned by Cardinal Scipione Borghese. Unlike Michelangelo's contemplative David, Bernini captures the biblical hero in dynamic action, mid-throw with his sling.

title: David and Goliath
subtitle: Titian · 1542-1544 · Oil on canvas (ceiling)

David and Goliath

David and Goliath - The story of the young shepherd David defeating the Philistine giant Goliath with a sling and stone.
Description
One of three dramatic ceiling paintings, originally for Santo Spirito. Walter Friedlaender called these paintings "manifestations of genius unprecedented even in Titian's own work" for their impassioned power of movement and daring use of foreshortening. Highly influential on Baroque painting.

title: David and Goliath
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1509 · Fresco

David and Goliath

Medium: Fresco
Date: 1509
Biblical Context
David and Goliath - The young shepherd David defeats the giant Philistine warrior Goliath (1 Samuel 17).
Description
One of the corner spandrels of the Sistine Chapel ceiling, depicting Old Testament scenes of salvation. Central interlocked figures create a clear narrative event—David is shown at the moment of striking down the giant Goliath. The dramatic composition emphasizes the physical struggle between the two figures.

title: Dante Before the City of Florence
subtitle: Domenico di Michelino · 1465 · Painting
content:
Dante Before the City of Florence

Location: Florence Cathedral, Florence
Medium: Painting
Date: 1465
Source: self-research
Description
Also known as "La Divina Commedia illumina Firenze" (The Divine Comedy Illuminates Florence), this painting shows Dante holding a copy of the Divine Comedy, with Mount Purgatory and the city of Florence behind him. The work honors Dante Alighieri, Florence's greatest poet, who was exiled from the city in 1302.

title: Danaë
subtitle: Correggio · c. 1531 · Oil on canvas
content:
Danaë
Wikipedia)

Location: Galleria Borghese, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1531
Source: self-research

Danaë - An Argive princess visited by Zeus in the form of a shower of gold, who bore the hero Perseus.
Description
A sensuous depiction of the mythological princess Danaë receiving Zeus in the form of a shower of gold. Part of a series of paintings on the loves of Jupiter commissioned by Federico II Gonzaga.

title: Dacian Prisoner Statues
subtitle: c. AD 107–117 (reign of Trajan); reused AD 315 · Pavonazzetto marble (purple-veined)
content:
Dacian Prisoner Statues
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Trajanic era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Pavonazzetto marble (purple-veined)
Date: c. AD 107–117 (reign of Trajan); reused AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
Eight statues of captured Dacian prisoners standing atop the Corinthian columns framing the attic level of the arch. Taken from the Forum of Trajan, these over-life-size figures depict barbarian captives in characteristic Dacian dress — beards, long hair, belted tunics, and trousers. Carved from distinctive purple-veined pavonazzetto marble, they symbolize Roman military dominance and were recontextualized to glorify Constantine's victories.

title: Curia Julia
subtitle: 44 BC (begun by Julius Caesar); completed by Augustus
content:
Curia Julia
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Senate House
Date: 44 BC (begun by Julius Caesar); completed by Augustus
Source: self-research
Description
The third named curia, or senate house, in ancient Rome. Julius Caesar began construction to replace the earlier Curia Cornelia as part of his redesign of the Forum. The building's remarkably well-preserved brick exterior survives because it was converted into the church of Sant'Adriano al Foro in the 7th century. The interior retains its original marble floor in opus sectile and contains the Plutei of Trajan, important relief sculptures.

title: Crucifixion

Crucifixion

A predella work with traditional composition from one of the founders of the Renaissance style of painting in Venice. Jacopo was the patriarch of the famous Bellini family of painters.

title: Crucifixion

Crucifixion

content:
Crucifix
Wikipedia)

Date: c. 1290–1300

Crucifixion - The death of Jesus Christ on the cross at Golgotha, as described in all four Gospels (Matthew 27:32-56, Mark 15:21-41, Luke 23:26-49, John 19:17-37). This central event in Christian theology represents Christ's sacrifice for the redemption of humanity's sins.

The earliest known artwork by Giotto. Revolutionary in its naturalistic depiction of Christ's suffering body, departing from the rigid Byzantine tradition.

Crossing of the Red Sea

Parting of the Red Sea - Moses parts the Red Sea to allow the Israelites to escape Egypt, then the waters return to drown the pursuing Egyptian army.

A fresco in the Chapel of Eleonora di Toledo depicting the Israelites crossing the Red Sea from the Book of Exodus, combined with Moses commissioning Joshua from the Book of Numbers. Notable for its dense, complex composition with numerous figures in Mannerist style.

title: Creation of Sun, Moon and Plants
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1511 · Fresco
content:
Creation of Sun, Moon and Plants
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1511
Biblical Context
Creation - God creates the heavens and the earth (Genesis 1:14-19).
Description
Completed in 7 days. Shows God creating the sun and moon with outstretched arms, commanding the celestial bodies into existence. In the same panel, God is shown a second time from behind, creating the plants. This dual depiction of God in one scene is a compositional innovation.

title: Creation of Adam
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1508-1512 · Fresco
content:
Creation of Adam
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1508-1512
Biblical Context
Creation of Adam - God creates the first man from the dust of the ground and breathes life into him (Genesis 2:7).
Description
Completed in 17 days. Painted after the successes of Julius II's army, with an increase in figure size compared to earlier scenes. God, absent from the first four scenes and standing on earth in the Creation of Eve, now moves through heaven in the last four scenes.
The near-touching fingers of God and Adam has become one of the most replicated religious images in history. The composition shows the reclining Adam receiving the spark of life from God, who floats in a billowing cloak surrounded by angels.

content:
Creation of Adam

Biblical Context
Creation of Adam - God creates the first man from the dust of the ground (Genesis 2:7).

Relief sculpture depicting the Creation of Adam.

title: Cosmatesque Pavement
subtitle: Cosmati · 12th century · Marble inlay (porphyry, serpentine, giallo antico)
content:
Cosmatesque Pavement

The nave floor is a masterpiece of Cosmatesque opus sectile work, featuring elaborate geometric patterns of inlaid colored marble. Dominated by an enormous porphyry roundel with intricate patterning using purple-crimson porphyry, dark green serpentine, and yellow giallo antico marble set in white marble matrices.

Coronation of the Virgin

Coronation of the Virgin - Christ crowning Mary as Queen of Heaven, based on Catholic tradition and Revelation 12:1.

A 15th-century fresco attributed to the Tuscan school, located in the second niche of the Pantheon. It depicts the traditional subject of Christ crowning Mary as Queen of Heaven.

title: Coronation of the Virgin
subtitle: Lorenzo Monaco · 1414 · Tempera on panel
content:
Coronation of the Virgin
Wikipedia)
Artist: Lorenzo Monaco
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: 1414
Biblical Context
Coronation of the Virgin - The Virgin Mary being crowned Queen of Heaven by Christ. While not directly described in scripture, this scene represents a tradition in Catholic theology following Mary's Assumption into heaven.
Description
A masterpiece of the International Gothic style. Originally in the Camaldolese monastery of Santa Maria degli Angeli.

title: Constantinian Frieze (South and West Sides: Departure from Milan, Siege of Verona, Battle of the Milvian Bridge)
subtitle: c. AD 312–315 · Marble relief
content:
Constantinian Frieze (South and West Sides: Departure from Milan, Siege of Verona, Battle of the Milvian Bridge)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Constantinian era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. AD 312–315
Source: self-research
Description
The horizontal frieze running below the Hadrianic roundels is the primary Constantinian-era sculptural contribution, depicting scenes from Constantine's Italian campaign against Maxentius. On the west side, the army departs from Milan (Mediolanum). On the south side, the narrative continues with the siege of Verona and culminates in the Battle of the Milvian Bridge, showing Constantine's soldiers on the bridge while Maxentius' troops drown in the Tiber. The style marks a dramatic departure from the classicizing spolia above — figures are stocky with large heads, arranged in rigid frontal rows with minimal spatial depth, reflecting the late antique shift toward hieratic, symbolic representation.

title: Constantinian Frieze (North and East Sides: Entry into Rome, Oration in the Forum, Largesse)
subtitle: c. AD 312–315 · Marble relief
content:
Constantinian Frieze (North and East Sides: Entry into Rome, Oration in the Forum, Largesse)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Constantinian era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. AD 312–315
Source: self-research
Description
The frieze continues on the east side with the victorious army entering Rome (adventus). On the north side, two panels show Constantine delivering a speech (oratio) in the Roman Forum from the Rostra, and distributing largesse (liberalitas) to the Roman people. These scenes emphasize Constantine's civic virtues alongside his military triumph. The oratio panel notably includes recognizable architectural landmarks of the Forum. The flat, frontal style of these reliefs contrasts sharply with the deeply modeled classicism of the reused 2nd-century panels above them.

title: The Confirmation of the Franciscan Rule by Pope Honorius III
subtitle: Domenico Ghirlandaio · 1482–1485 · Fresco
content:
The Confirmation of the Franciscan Rule by Pope Honorius III

Medium: Fresco

Four portraits on the right side of the composition are Antonio Pucci, Lorenzo the Magnificent, Francesco and Federigo Sassetti.

title: Competition Panel (Ghiberti)

content:
Competition Panel (Ghiberti)

Ghiberti's winning competition panel for the second set of bronze doors for the Florence Baptistery. Only the Isaac figure was cast separately, making the whole piece lighter but stronger.

content:
Competition Panel (Brunelleschi)

Brunelleschi's competition panel for the second set of bronze doors for the Florence Baptistery. The servant in the left's pose is derived from the Spinario, a popular Roman sculpture. Each figure was cast individually.

title: Column of Phocas
subtitle: 608 AD
content:
Column of Phocas
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Monumental Column
Date: 608 AD
Source: self-research
Description
A Roman monumental column, the last monument erected in the Roman Forum. Built when Rome was part of the Eastern Roman Empire after its reconquest from the Ostrogoths. The column was dedicated to the Byzantine Emperor Phocas by the exarch Smaragdus, possibly in gratitude for Phocas's gift of the Pantheon to Pope Boniface IV.

title: Column Base Reliefs (Victories and Captives)
subtitle: c. AD 312–315 · Marble relief
content:
Column Base Reliefs (Victories and Captives)
Artist: Unknown Roman sculptors (Constantinian era)
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. AD 312–315
Source: self-research
Description
Relief panels on the pedestals of the freestanding columns show Victories carrying trophies, with Roman soldiers and bound captives. These small-scale reliefs echo the triumphal imagery of the arch's larger sculptural program and are executed in the same late antique style as the Constantinian frieze.

title: Colossus of Nero
subtitle: c. AD 64-68 · Bronze
content:
Colossus of Nero
Wikipedia
Artist: Zenodorus
Location: Colosseum, Rome
Medium: Bronze
Date: c. AD 64-68
Source: self-research
Description
A 30-metre (98 ft) bronze statue originally created as a portrait of Emperor Nero in the vestibule of his Domus Aurea. Later modified by Nero's successors into a statue of the sun god Sol, it was moved to a spot outside the Flavian Amphitheatre, which became known as the Colosseum by its proximity to the Colossus. The statue no longer survives.

title: Coffered Ceiling
subtitle: c. 1493–1500 · Gilded and carved wood
content:
Coffered Ceiling
Artist: Giuliano da Sangallo (attributed)
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Gilded and carved wood
Date: c. 1493–1500
Source: self-research
Description
The magnificent coffered ceiling of the central nave, traditionally attributed to Giuliano da Sangallo, was commissioned by Pope Alexander VI Borgia. According to tradition, it was gilded with the first gold brought from the Americas by Christopher Columbus, presented to the Pope by Ferdinand and Isabella of Spain.

title: Circus of Maxentius
subtitle: AD 306-312
content:
Circus of Maxentius
Wikipedia
Location: Via Appia Antica, Rome
Type: Ancient Chariot Racing Circus
Date: AD 306-312
Source: self-research
Description
Part of a complex built by Emperor Maxentius between the second and third miles of the Via Appia, including a palace and chariot racing track. Situated between the catacombs of San Sebastiano and the Tomb of Caecilia Metella, it is now part of the Appian Way Regional Park.

title: Ciborium of Deodatus
subtitle: 1294 · Marble with Cosmatesque decoration
content:
Ciborium of Deodatus

Location: Santa Maria in Cosmedin, Rome
Medium: Marble with Cosmatesque decoration
Date: 1294
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Annunciation - The front face features a mosaic scene of the Annunciation facing the nave.
Description
A Gothic-style altar canopy (baldacchino) signed "Deodatus me fecit" ("Deodatus made me"). In the Florentine Gothic style with Cosmatesque inlay decoration, it is supported by four red granite columns from Aswan, Egypt, topped with Ionic capitals. The front face features a mosaic scene of the Annunciation facing the nave.

title: Christ and Saint Thomas
subtitle: Andrea del Verrocchio · 1467–1483 · Bronze
content:
Christ and Saint Thomas
Wikipedia)
Artist: Andrea del Verrocchio
Location: Orsanmichele, Florence
Medium: Bronze
Date: 1467–1483

Depicts the moment when the apostle Thomas, who had doubted the resurrection, touches the wounds of the risen Christ. From John 20:24-29, Jesus says to Thomas, "Put your finger here; see my hands. Reach out your hand and put it into my side. Stop doubting and believe."
Description
Bronze sculpture group at Orsanmichele.

title: Chiesa di Santa Maria presso San Satiro
subtitle: 1482-1486 · Architecture
content:
Chiesa di Santa Maria presso San Satiro
Wikipedia
Architect: Donato Bramante
Location: Milan, Italy
Medium: Architecture
Date: 1482-1486
GoogleMap
Description
A carefully calculated illusion choir. Due to space constraints behind the altar, Bramante created a trompe-l'oeil apse that appears to have depth but is actually only about 97 cm deep. This is one of the earliest and most famous examples of perspective illusion in architecture.

title: Chapter House Fresco
subtitle: Andrea da Firenze · c. 1365–1367 · Fresco
content:
Chapter House Fresco
Artist: Andrea da Firenze
Location: Santa Maria Novella, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 1365–1367
Description
Fresco in the Chapter House (Spanish Chapel) at Santa Maria Novella, depicting the "Triumph of the Church."

title: Cestello Annunciation
subtitle: Sandro Botticelli · 1489–1490 · Tempera on panel
content:
Cestello Annunciation
Wikipedia
Artist: Sandro Botticelli
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: 1489–1490
Biblical Context
Annunciation - The moment when the Angel Gabriel announced to the Virgin Mary that she would conceive and bear the Son of God, as described in Luke 1:26-38.
Description
The strong emotions and color suggest Botticelli may have been a listener to Girolamo Savonarola, a monk from Ferrara who became the prior of San Marco. Savonarola was a preacher who advocated the destruction of secular art and culture, and was later tortured and executed.

title: Cartoon for Philosophy
subtitle: Raphael · c. 1509-1510 · Charcoal and white chalk on paper
content:
Cartoon for Philosophy
Artist: Raphael
Location: Pinacoteca Ambrosiana, Milan
Medium: Charcoal and white chalk on paper
Date: c. 1509-1510
Description
The preparatory drawing (cartoon) for The School of Athens fresco in the Vatican. Shows Raphael's design process and the development of the composition before painting.

title: The Cardinal Virtues
subtitle: Raphael · 1511 · Fresco
content:
The Cardinal Virtues
Wikipedia)
Artist: Raphael
Location: Apostolic Palace, Vatican
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1511
Description
Three of the cardinal virtues—Fortitude, Prudence, and Temperance—are personified as statuesque women seated in a bucolic landscape. The theological virtues—Charity, Hope, and Faith—are depicted by putti.
Shows Michelangelo's stylistic influence but with less tension.

title: Cantoria (Luca della Robbia)
subtitle: Luca della Robbia · 1431–1438 · Marble
content:
Cantoria (Luca della Robbia)
Wikipedia)
Artist: Luca della Robbia
Location: Opera del Duomo Museum, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: 1431–1438
Source: my-study, self-research
Description
A marble singing gallery (cantoria) originally made for Florence Cathedral. The relief panels depict joyful children and youths singing, dancing, and playing musical instruments, illustrating Psalm 150.

title: Cantoria (Donatello)
subtitle: Donatello · 1433–1439 · Marble
content:
Cantoria (Donatello)
Wikipedia)
Artist: Donatello
Location: Opera del Duomo Museum, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: 1433–1439
Source: my-study, self-research
Description
Singing gallery (cantoria) originally made for Florence Cathedral. Donatello's companion singing gallery to della Robbia's cantoria. Features a continuous frieze of exuberant putti (cherubs) dancing behind columns, creating a sense of joyous movement and energy.

title: Calumny of Apelles
subtitle: Sandro Botticelli · c. 1494–1495 · Tempera on panel
content:
Calumny of Apelles
Wikipedia
Artist: Sandro Botticelli
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1494–1495
Description
A reconstruction of a lost painting by the ancient Greek painter Apelles, described by Lucian. May have been painted in defense of Girolamo Savonarola, depicting the dangers of false accusations.

title: Cain and Abel
subtitle: Titian · 1542-1544 · Oil on canvas (ceiling)
content:
Cain and Abel
Artist: Titian
Location: Santa Maria della Salute, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas (ceiling)
Date: 1542-1544
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Cain and Abel - The story of the first murder, in which Cain kills his brother Abel out of jealousy.
Description
Ceiling painting showing Cain killing his brother Abel. Part of Titian's Old Testament ceiling series, renowned for its powerful foreshortening and dynamic composition.

title: CIL 4.5296
subtitle: Before 79 AD · Graffito (scratched inscription)
content:
CIL 4.5296
Wikipedia
Artist: Anonymous
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Graffito (scratched inscription)
Date: Before 79 AD
Source: self-research
Description
One of the longest and most elaborate surviving graffiti texts from Pompeii, discovered in 1888. This nine-verse love poem may be the only known love poem from one woman to another from the Latin world. Written in the voice of a woman addressing another woman as "pupula" (my little darling), it represents a rare intimate glimpse into female relationships in antiquity.

title: Byzantine Mosaics of San Marco
subtitle: 11th-13th century (and later) · Gold and glass mosaic
content:
Byzantine Mosaics of San Marco
Artist: Various Byzantine and Venetian craftsmen
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Gold and glass mosaic
Date: 11th-13th century (and later)
Source: self-research
Description
The basilica features 8,000 square meters of mosaics illuminating the interior. The oldest surviving mosaic, depicting Saint Alipio, dates to 1260 and shows the translation of Saint Mark's relics from Alexandria, with merchants hiding the body beneath pork to avoid Muslim inspection.

title: Brutus
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1539-1540 · Marble bust
content:
Brutus
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Bargello, Florence
Medium: Marble bust
Date: c. 1539-1540
Source: self-research
Description
A marble bust of Marcus Junius Brutus, the only bust Michelangelo ever made. Commissioned after the assassination of Duke Alessandro de' Medici in 1537, it may represent a republican ideal—Brutus was celebrated in Florence as the slayer of the tyrant Julius Caesar.
The bust shows Brutus turning sharply to his left, with an intense expression and furrowed brow. The work was left unfinished, like many of Michelangelo's late sculptures, adding to its psychological intensity.

title: Brunelleschi Crucifix
subtitle: Filippo Brunelleschi · c. 1410-1415 · Polychrome painted pearwood
content:
Brunelleschi Crucifix
Wikipedia
Artist: Filippo Brunelleschi
Location: Santa Maria Novella, Florence (Gondi Chapel)
Medium: Polychrome painted pearwood
Date: c. 1410-1415
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Crucifixion - The death of Jesus Christ on the cross.
Description
A polychrome painted wooden sculpture located in the Gondi Chapel at the church of Santa Maria Novella. This idealized depiction of the crucifixion of Jesus measures around 170 cm × 170 cm.
This is the only surviving wooden sculpture by Brunelleschi; the only other known example, a wooden sculpture of Mary Magdalene at the church of Santo Spirito, was destroyed in a fire in 1471.
Art historian Luciano Bellosi described Brunelleschi's crucifix as "probably the first Renaissance work in the history of art," representing a definitive turn away from the stylised postures of Gothic sculpture and a return to the naturalism of classical sculpture. According to Vasari, Brunelleschi carved this crucifix in response to Donatello's crucifix at Santa Croce, which Brunelleschi criticized as depicting "a peasant on the Cross."

title: Bronze Pulpits
subtitle: Donatello · c. 1460-1466 · Bronze
content:
Bronze Pulpits
Artist: Donatello
Location: Basilica of San Lorenzo, Florence
Medium: Bronze
Date: c. 1460-1466
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Crucifixion, Lamentation - The pulpits depict scenes from the Passion and Resurrection of Christ.
Description
Donatello's final works, these two bronze pulpits in the nave of San Lorenzo depict the Passion and Resurrection of Christ with remarkable emotional intensity. The reliefs show scenes including the Crucifixion, Lamentation, Entombment, and Resurrection.
The pulpits were completed by Donatello's workshop after his death in 1466, and some scholars believe the finish shows hands other than the master's. The expressive, almost tortured style of these late works differs markedly from Donatello's earlier, more classical manner. Donatello is buried in San Lorenzo, near Cosimo de' Medici, his longtime patron.

title: Bronze Entrance Doors
subtitle: Igor Mitoraj · 2005 · Bronze
content:
Bronze Entrance Doors
Wikipedia
Artist: Igor Mitoraj
Location: Baths of Diocletian, Rome
Medium: Bronze
Date: 2005
Source: self-research
Description
Monumental bronze doors by the Polish sculptor Igor Mitoraj, installed at the entrance to the basilica. The left door depicts the Resurrection and the right door the Annunciation, rendered in Mitoraj's characteristic fragmented figural style.

title: Bronze David
subtitle: Donatello · c. 1440s · Bronze
content:
Bronze David
Wikipedia)
Artist: Donatello
Location: Bargello, Florence
Medium: Bronze
Date: c. 1440s
Biblical Context
David, the young shepherd who slew the giant Goliath with a stone from his sling, as told in 1 Samuel 17. This victory made him a hero of Israel and he later became king.
Description
First large-scale nude sculpture since antiquity. The first unsupported standing work of bronze cast during the Renaissance, and the first freestanding nude male sculpture made since antiquity. The pose is derived from contrapposto, with the left knee coming forward against the cloth. David is depicted with an enigmatic smile, posed with his foot on Goliath's severed head.

title: The Brazen Serpent
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1511-1512 · Fresco
content:
The Brazen Serpent
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Sistine Chapel, Vatican City
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1511-1512
Biblical Context
Brazen Serpent - Moses erects a bronze serpent to heal Israelites bitten by fiery serpents (Numbers 21:4-9).
Description
One of the last of Michelangelo's works on the ceiling, located in a corner spandrel. Shows more complex groupings of interlocking figures than earlier works. The Israelites writhe in agony from the serpent bites, while those who look upon the bronze serpent that Moses has raised are healed.
This scene was traditionally understood as a prefiguration of Christ's crucifixion, as referenced in John 3:14: "As Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, even so must the Son of Man be lifted up."

title: Boy with a Basket of Fruit
subtitle: Caravaggio · c. 1593 · Oil on canvas
content:
Boy with a Basket of Fruit
Wikipedia
Artist: Caravaggio
Location: Galleria Borghese, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1593
Source: self-research
Description
An early work showing a sensuous young man holding a basket of meticulously rendered fruit. The painting demonstrates Caravaggio's innovative approach to still life and his use of a model from the streets of Rome.

title: Bocca della Verità
subtitle: 1st century AD (placed in church portico 1632) · Marble (pavonazzetto from Phrygia)
content:
Bocca della Verità
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown (ancient Roman)
Location: Santa Maria in Cosmedin, Rome
Medium: Marble (pavonazzetto from Phrygia)
Date: 1st century AD (placed in church portico 1632)
Source: self-research
Description
A large ancient Roman marble disc (1.75 meters across, 19 cm thick, weighing approximately 1,200 kg) bearing a bearded face in shallow relief with pierced eyes, nostrils, and mouth. Thought to represent an ocean deity or river god, it may have originally served as a drain cover or fountain. According to medieval legend, it will bite off the hand of any liar who places their hand in its mouth. It stands against the left wall of the church portico.

title: Birth of Venus
subtitle: Sandro Botticelli · c. mid-1480s · Tempera on canvas
content:
Birth of Venus
Wikipedia
Artist: Sandro Botticelli
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on canvas
Date: c. mid-1480s
Description
Depicts the goddess Venus emerging from the sea as a fully grown woman. In the left are Zephyrus (the wind god) and a nymph.

title: Belvedere Torso
subtitle: Apollonios · 1st century BC (likely a copy of an earlier 2nd century BC Greek bronze) · Marble
content:
Belvedere Torso
Wikipedia
Artist: Apollonios
Location: Vatican Museums, Vatican City
Medium: Marble
Date: 1st century BC (likely a copy of an earlier 2nd century BC Greek bronze)
Source: Self-researched
Description
A 1.59-metre-tall fragmentary marble statue of a seated male nude, known to be in Rome since the 1430s. The identity of the figure remains debated—traditionally identified as Hercules seated on the lion skin, though recent scholarship suggests Ajax contemplating suicide.
The statue profoundly influenced Renaissance artists, particularly Michelangelo, who called it his "teacher" and used it as inspiration for figures on the Sistine Chapel ceiling. When Pope Julius II asked Michelangelo to complete the statue with limbs and a head, he refused, declaring it too beautiful to alter.

title: Bearded Slave
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1525-1530 · Marble
content:
Bearded Slave
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Galleria dell'Accademia, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 1525-1530
Source: self-research
Description
The most finished of the Florentine Prisoners, named for the thick, curly beard covering the figure's face. Part of the unfinished series intended for the Tomb of Pope Julius II. The clearly defined muscles of the torso reveal Michelangelo's deep study of human anatomy.

title: Battle of the Centaurs
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1492 · Marble relief
content:
Battle of the Centaurs
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Casa Buonarroti, Florence
Medium: Marble relief
Date: c. 1492
Description
A marble relief depicting the mythological battle between the Lapiths and Centaurs, created when Michelangelo was about 17 and living in the household of Lorenzo de' Medici. The dynamic composition of intertwined nude figures demonstrates his early interest in the human form in motion.
This was the last work Michelangelo created while under the patronage of Lorenzo de' Medici, who died shortly after its completion. The subject was suggested to Michelangelo by the classical scholar and poet Poliziano, inspired by a classical relief created by Bertoldo di Giovanni. Though unfinished, it demonstrates Michelangelo's fascination with movement and human anatomy that would characterize his mature work.

title: Battle of San Romano
subtitle: Paolo Uccello · c. 1435–1460 · Tempera on panel
content:
Battle of San Romano
Wikipedia
Artist: Paolo Uccello
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Tempera on panel
Date: c. 1435–1460
Description
Commemorates Florence's victory over the Sienese in 1432. One of three panels (others in London and Paris). Demonstrates Uccello's fascination with perspective.

title: The Battle of Marciano in Val di Chiana
subtitle: Giorgio Vasari · 1555-1572 · Fresco
content:
The Battle of Marciano in Val di Chiana
Wikipedia
Artist: Giorgio Vasari
Location: Palazzo Vecchio, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1555-1572
Source: self-research
Description
One of the large frescoes on the walls of the Salone dei Cinquecento, depicting the 1554 battle in which Florence defeated the Republic of Siena. This fresco contains the mysterious inscription "Cerca Trova" (Seek and You Shall Find), which some interpret as a hint that Leonardo's Battle of Anghiari may survive beneath.

title: Battle of Cascina
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1504-1506 · Fresco (never completed)
content:
Battle of Cascina
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Palazzo Vecchio, Florence
Medium: Fresco (never completed)
Date: 1504-1506
Source: self-research
Description
A fresco commissioned for the Palazzo Vecchio to face Leonardo's Battle of Anghiari. Michelangelo only completed the preparatory cartoon before being called to Rome by Pope Julius II. The famous cartoon, showing Florentine soldiers surprised while bathing, was studied and copied by many Renaissance artists before being lost.

title: The Battle of Anghiari
subtitle: Leonardo da Vinci · 1505 · Fresco (lost)
content:
The Battle of Anghiari
Wikipedia)
Artist: Leonardo da Vinci
Location: Palazzo Vecchio, Florence
Medium: Fresco (lost)
Date: 1505
Source: self-research
Description
A lost painting commissioned for the Salone dei Cinquecento. The central scene depicted four men on raging war horses fighting for possession of a standard at the Battle of Anghiari in 1440. Leonardo's experimental techniques caused the paint to deteriorate. Some believe it may survive beneath Vasari's later frescoes, hinted at by the inscription "Cerca Trova" (Seek and You Shall Find).

title: Basilica Julia
subtitle: Begun 46 BC by Julius Caesar; completed by Augustus 12 AD
content:
Basilica Julia
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Civil Basilica
Date: Begun 46 BC by Julius Caesar; completed by Augustus 12 AD
Source: self-research
Description
A large civil basilica that served as the headquarters for the centumviri, a judicial court dealing with matters of inheritance. The three-story marble structure was one of the largest buildings in the Forum. Today only the foundations, steps, and a few column bases and brick piers remain. Game boards scratched into the marble steps by bored Romans can still be seen.

title: Basilica Graffiti
subtitle: Before 79 AD · Graffiti (scratched inscriptions)
content:
Basilica Graffiti
Artist: Anonymous (multiple authors)
Location: Pompeii Archaeological Park, Campania
Medium: Graffiti (scratched inscriptions)
Date: Before 79 AD
Source: self-research
Description
The Basilica, Pompeii's main judicial and commercial building, contained numerous graffiti including the crude inscription "Lucilla made money from her body." Such graffiti demonstrates that Romans from all social classes participated in wall writing, using public spaces to spread gossip, insults, and commentary.

title: Basilica Aemilia
subtitle: 179 BC (original); 34 BC (rebuilt by Paullus Aemilius Lepidus)
content:
Basilica Aemilia
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Civil Basilica
Date: 179 BC (original); 34 BC (rebuilt by Paullus Aemilius Lepidus)
Source: self-research
Description
A civil basilica on the northeast side of the Roman Forum, described by Pliny as one of the most beautiful buildings in Rome. Used for business and banking. Coins melted into the floor during the Sack of Rome (410) by Alaric are still visible. A sculptural frieze depicting scenes from early Roman history survives and is displayed in the Antiquarium of the Forum.

title: Baroncelli Chapel Frescoes
subtitle: Taddeo Gaddi · c. 1328–1330 · Fresco
content:
Baroncelli Chapel Frescoes
Wikipedia
Artist: Taddeo Gaddi
Location: Santa Croce, Florence
Medium: Fresco
Date: c. 1328–1330
Description
Frescoes in the Baroncelli Chapel by Bernardo Daddi, a follower of Giotto.

title: Baptistery Ceiling Mosaic
subtitle: Coppo di Marcovaldo · c. 1270–1300 · Mosaic
content:
Baptistery Ceiling Mosaic
Artist: Coppo di Marcovaldo
Location: Florence Baptistery, Florence
Medium: Mosaic
Date: c. 1270–1300
Description
Part of the ceiling of the Baptistery of Florence, representing the Italo-Byzantine style of the Duecento.

title: The Baptism of Jesus
subtitle: Carlo Maratta · 1697 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Baptism of Jesus
Wikipedia
Artist: Carlo Maratta
Location: Baths of Diocletian, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1697
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Baptism of Christ - The baptism of Jesus by John the Baptist in the Jordan River, when the heavens opened, the Holy Spirit descended like a dove, and a voice from heaven declared "This is my beloved Son." (Matthew 3:13-17)
Description
Painted for St. Peter's Basilica, this monumental altarpiece depicts the baptism of Christ by John the Baptist. It was among the first large paintings moved from St. Peter's to Santa Maria degli Angeli, transferred by order of Pope Benedict XIII after Maratta's death in 1713.

title: The Baptism of Christ
subtitle: Andrea del Verrocchio · c. 1472–1475 · Oil and tempera on panel
content:
The Baptism of Christ
Wikipedia)
Artist: Andrea del Verrocchio (with Leonardo da Vinci)
Location: Uffizi Gallery, Florence
Medium: Oil and tempera on panel
Date: c. 1472–1475
Biblical Context
Baptism of Christ - The moment when John the Baptist baptizes Jesus in the Jordan River. As described in Matthew 3:13-17, the heavens opened and the Spirit of God descended like a dove, while a voice from heaven declared "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased."
Description
Painted primarily by Verrocchio, but the leftmost angel, the water and rocks behind the angel are attributed to his young apprentice Leonardo da Vinci.

title: Bacchus, Venus and Ariadne
subtitle: Tintoretto · 1576-1577 · Oil on canvas
content:
Bacchus, Venus and Ariadne
Wikipedia)
Artist: Tintoretto
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1576-1577
Source: self-research
Mythological Context
Ariadne - Cretan princess abandoned by Theseus on Naxos, discovered by Dionysus/Bacchus who made her his immortal wife.
Description
One of four mythological paintings in the Sala dell'Anticollegio, originally commissioned to celebrate the government of Doge Girolamo Priuli. The painting depicts Bacchus crowning Ariadne with a ring of stars while Venus watches, symbolizing Venice's heavenly gifts and beauty.

title: Bacchus
subtitle: Michelangelo · 1496-1497 · Marble
content:
Bacchus
Wikipedia)
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Bargello, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: 1496-1497
Description
A marble sculpture of the Roman god of wine, depicted nude with vine leaves and grapes, his body swaying as if affected by alcohol. Michelangelo was paid 160 florins for this work. The sculpture demonstrates his ability to capture both classical ideals and naturalistic observation.

title: Awakening Slave
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1525-1530 · Marble
content:
Awakening Slave
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Galleria dell'Accademia, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 1525-1530
Source: self-research
Description
A 2.67m high unfinished marble statue, one of the 'Prisoners' series for the tomb of Pope Julius II. The figure appears to be struggling to emerge from the stone, dramatically illustrating Michelangelo's belief that the sculptor's task was to liberate the figure already present within the marble block.

title: Atys-Amorino
subtitle: Donatello · c. 1440 · Bronze
content:
Atys-Amorino
Wikipedia
Artist: Donatello
Location: Bargello, Florence
Medium: Bronze
Date: c. 1440
Description
Bronze sculpture combining attributes of Eros and Attis.

title: Atlas Slave
subtitle: Michelangelo · c. 1525-1530 · Marble
content:
Atlas Slave
Wikipedia
Artist: Michelangelo
Location: Galleria dell'Accademia, Florence
Medium: Marble
Date: c. 1525-1530
Source: self-research
Description
A 2.77m high unfinished marble statue, one of the 'Prisoners' series originally intended for the tomb of Pope Julius II. The figure appears burdened by a massive weight on his head, giving the sculpture its name. After Michelangelo's death, it was given to Grand Duke Cosimo I and installed in the Boboli Gardens until 1909.

title: Athletes Mosaics
subtitle: c. 4th century AD (later restoration of original baths) · Polychrome mosaic
content:
Athletes Mosaics
Artist: Unknown Roman artisans
Original Location: Baths of Caracalla, Rome
Current Location: Gregoriano Profano Museum, Vatican Museums
Medium: Polychrome mosaic
Date: c. 4th century AD (later restoration of original baths)
Source: self-research
Description
Two famous polychrome mosaics depicting athletes and judges of competitions, discovered in 1824 in the exedrae on the east and west sides of the baths complex. The figures are divided into square panels with busts and rectangular panels with full-length figures. Athletes are shown with their hair gathered into a cirrus (characteristic knot at the nape of the neck).

title: Assumption of the Virgin
subtitle: Titian · 1515-1518 · Oil on panel
content:
Assumption of the Virgin
Wikipedia)
Artist: Titian
Location: Basilica di Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari, Venice
Medium: Oil on panel
Date: 1515-1518
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Assumption of Mary - The belief that Mary, mother of Jesus, was assumed bodily into Heaven at the end of her earthly life.
Description
Titian's most famous painting, commissioned for the Basilica and remaining in its original position on the high altar. The largest altarpiece in Venice, with figures well over life-size. The work established Titian as the most prominent painter of 16th century Venice. Also known as the Assunta.

title: Ascension Cupola Mosaic
subtitle: 12th-13th century · Gold and glass mosaic
content:
Ascension Cupola Mosaic
Artist: Byzantine and Venetian mosaicists
Location: Saint Mark's Basilica, Venice
Medium: Gold and glass mosaic
Date: 12th-13th century
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Ascension of Jesus - The Ascension depicts Jesus ascending bodily to Heaven forty days after his Resurrection.
Description
The central dome of the basilica depicting Christ's Ascension into heaven. The composition shows Christ in glory surrounded by angels, with the Virgin Mary and the Apostles below. One of the finest examples of Byzantine-influenced mosaic art in the Western world.

title: Arithmetic and Geometry
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · 1556-1557 · Oil on canvas
content:
Arithmetic and Geometry
Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Biblioteca Marciana, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Dimensions: 230 cm diameter (tondo)
Date: 1556-1557
Source: self-research
Description
One of Veronese's three ceiling tondi in the library, depicting allegorical figures representing Arithmetic and Geometry. The paintings were commissioned as part of the library's elaborate ceiling decoration.

title: Aristotle
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · 1560s · Oil on canvas
content:
Aristotle
Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Biblioteca Marciana, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: 1560s
Source: self-research
Description
The companion piece to Plato, positioned on the opposite side of the entrance portal. Part of the philosopher portrait series decorating the library walls.

title: Arch of Titus
subtitle: c. 81 AD
content:
Arch of Titus
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Triumphal Arch
Date: c. 81 AD
Source: self-research
Description
A 1st-century AD honorific arch located on the Via Sacra, just to the south-east of the Roman Forum. Constructed by Emperor Domitian shortly after the death of his older brother Titus to commemorate Titus's official deification and the victory over the Jewish rebellion in Judaea. The inner panels contain famous reliefs depicting the spoils of Jerusalem, including the Menorah being carried in triumph. It served as the model for many later triumphal arches including the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.

title: Arch of Septimius Severus
subtitle: 203 AD
content:
Arch of Septimius Severus
Wikipedia
Location: Roman Forum, Rome
Type: Triumphal Arch
Date: 203 AD
Source: self-research
Description
A white marble triumphal arch at the northwestern end of the Roman Forum, dedicated to commemorate the Parthian victories of Emperor Septimius Severus and his two sons, Caracalla and Geta. Standing about 23 meters high and 25 meters wide, it features elaborate relief panels depicting battle scenes. After Caracalla had Geta assassinated, Geta's image and inscriptions were removed from the arch in an act of damnatio memoriae.

title: Arch of Constantine
subtitle: AD 315 · Brick-faced concrete, marble
content:
Arch of Constantine
Wikipedia
Artist: Unknown Roman architects
Location: Arch of Constantine, Rome (near Colosseum)
Medium: Brick-faced concrete, marble
Date: AD 315
Source: self-research
Description
A triumphal arch dedicated to Emperor Constantine the Great, commemorating his victory over Maxentius at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge in AD 312. Situated between the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill, it is the largest Roman triumphal arch, measuring 21m high, 25.9m wide, and 7.4m deep with three bays decorated with reliefs, many of which were reused from earlier monuments.

title: Arcade Statues
subtitle: c. AD 80 · Marble, bronze
content:
Arcade Statues
Artist: Various Roman sculptors
Location: Colosseum, Rome
Medium: Marble, bronze
Date: c. AD 80
Source: self-research
Description
Originally 156 statues of gods, heroes, and demigods were placed in the outer arcades of the 2nd and 3rd tiers of the Colosseum. Prominent Romans had their portraits displayed on the 1st tier, while the imperial family's portraits adorned the imperial box. None of these statues survive today; their existence is documented through the reliefs from the Tomb of the Haterii and ancient coins.

title: Apse Mosaic: Coronation of the Virgin
subtitle: Jacopo Torriti · c. 1295–1296 · Mosaic
content:
Apse Mosaic: Coronation of the Virgin
Artist: Jacopo Torriti
Location: Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome
Medium: Mosaic
Date: c. 1295–1296
Source: self-research
Biblical Context
Coronation of the Virgin - Christ crowning the Virgin Mary as Queen of Heaven.
Description
Commissioned by Pope Nicholas IV, this monumental apse mosaic depicts Christ crowning the Virgin Mary, both seated on a shared throne against a deep blue background filled with swirling acanthus scrolls. Below are five scenes from the Life of the Virgin: the Annunciation, Nativity, Adoration of the Magi, Presentation in the Temple, and the Dormition. It is the largest single mosaic image surviving from 13th-century Italy and one of the earliest monumental depictions of the Coronation of the Virgin.

title: Apse and Presbytery Frescoes
subtitle: Andrea Pozzo · 1685-1701 · Fresco
content:
Apse and Presbytery Frescoes
Artist: Andrea Pozzo
Location: Sant'Ignazio, Rome
Medium: Fresco
Date: 1685-1701
Source: self-research
Description
The frescoes illustrate key moments from Saint Ignatius's life and the founding of the Society of Jesus, including the siege of Pamplona, service to plague victims, Francis Borgia's entry into the order, Francis Xavier's mission to the Indies, and the famous La Storta vision where Christ appeared to Ignatius.

title: The Apparition of the Virgin Mary to Saint Bruno
subtitle: Giovanni Odazzi · c. 1700 · Oil on canvas
content:
The Apparition of the Virgin Mary to Saint Bruno
Wikipedia
Artist: Giovanni Odazzi
Location: Baths of Diocletian, Rome
Medium: Oil on canvas
Date: c. 1700
Source: self-research
Description
Painted for the 1700 Jubilee, this Baroque altarpiece in the Chapel of St. Bruno depicts the Virgin Mary appearing to St. Bruno, founder of the Carthusian Order. Appropriate for its setting, as the church was part of a Carthusian monastery.

title: Apotheosis of Venice
subtitle: Paolo Veronese · 1585 · Oil on canvas (ceiling)
content:
Apotheosis of Venice
Artist: Paolo Veronese
Location: Doge's Palace, Venice
Medium: Oil on canvas (ceiling)
Date: 1585
Source: self-research

A ceiling painting in the Chamber of the Great Council celebrating Venice personified, surrounded by allegorical figures representing Peace, Justice, and Fame. A masterpiece of illusionistic ceiling painting.

The Papal Basilica of Saint Peter in the Vatican is a church of the Italian High Renaissance located in Vatican City. It was initially planned in the 15th century by Pope Nicholas V and then Pope Julius II to replace the ageing Old St. Peter's Basilica, which was built in the fourth century by Roman emperor Constantine the Great.
Donato Bramante was the original architect. 12 architects and 22 popes later, the building was finally completed, but with Michelangelesque shell and Baroque extensions, the original design is barely recognizable. When Raphael took over as architect in 1514 he commented "the greatest building work ever seen would cost more than a million gold." To finance the construction the Vatican encouraged the sale of indulgences. The area around the dome was built largely as Bramante planned it.

The Sistine Chapel is a chapel in the Apostolic Palace, the pope's official residence in Vatican City. Originally known as the Cappella Magna, it takes its name from Pope Sixtus IV, who had it built between 1473 and 1481. Since that time, it has served as a place of both religious and functionary papal activity. Today, it is the site of the papal conclave.
To view the elements correctly, a viewer must face each of the four walls in turn, and in order to read the narrative scenes right side up, we must start at the entrance and move toward the altar. This means that the narrative sequence must be read backward. Reading backward, we pass through the sin of drunken Noah, the sin of Adam and Eve, to scenes that emphasize God's titanic power as he creates human and matter.

A minor basilica dedicated to the Virgin Mary, located in the rione of Ripa at the site of the ancient Forum Boarium. Constructed in the 6th century as a diaconia for Greek immigrants celebrating Eastern rites, it was expanded in the 8th century and renovated in the 12th century when a campanile was added. A Baroque facade of 1718 was removed in 1894–1899, restoring the exterior to 12th-century form. The church currently serves the Melkite Greek Catholic community of Rome. Best known for the Bocca della Verità in its portico, it also contains outstanding Cosmatesque marble work and an important early medieval mosaic fragment.

Over 11,000 graffiti samples have been uncovered in the excavations of Pompeii, providing an unparalleled window into daily Roman life. The inscriptions—scratched or painted on walls of houses, taverns, brothels, and public buildings—range from love declarations and political slogans to literary quotations, advertisements, and crude humor. These texts offer examples of Vulgar Latin as it was actually spoken, contrasting with the formal language of classical writers.

The Pantheon is an ancient 2nd-century Roman temple and, since AD 609, a Catholic church called the Basilica of St. Mary and the Martyrs. It is perhaps the most famous and architecturally most influential rotunda, renowned for its massive unreinforced concrete dome with a central oculus open to the sky. Tomb of Raphael
Raphael requested to be buried in the Pantheon, making him the first artist to be accorded such an honour. His sarcophagus is in the third aedicule, surmounted by Lorenzetto's Madonna del Sasso. The Latin epitaph, composed by Pietro Bembo, reads: "Here lies Raphael, by whom Nature herself feared to be outdone while he lived, and when he died, feared that she herself would die."
Tomb of Annibale Carracci
The Baroque painter was buried near Raphael in 1609, as he had requested. Annibale greatly admired Raphael and wished to rest beside him.
Tomb of Baldassare Peruzzi
The Renaissance architect and painter was buried near Raphael in 1536. Known for designing the Villa Farnesina and his work on St. Peter's Basilica.
Tomb of Victor Emmanuel II
The first King of a united Italy (r. 1861-1878), known as the "Father of the Fatherland," is entombed in the second chapel.

The second King of Italy (r. 1878-1900) was buried opposite his father's tomb in 1900.

title: Palatine Hill
subtitle: Rome, Italy
content:
Palatine Hill
Wikipedia
GoogleMap
Rome, Italy
Type: Archaeological Site / Open-air Museum
Source: self-research
One of the most ancient parts of Rome and the centremost of the seven hills, the Palatine has been called "the first nucleus of the Roman Empire." From the start of the Empire (27 BC), Augustus built his palace here and the hill gradually became the exclusive domain of emperors. The site now functions as a large open-air museum, while the Palatine Museum houses many finds from excavations.
Structures
House of Augustus
Wikipedia
Also known as the Domus Augusti, this house on the southwestern corner of the Palatine served as the primary residence of Emperor Augustus (c. 30 BC). The western rooms, believed to be private living quarters, feature extensive Second Style wall decorations including the famous Room of the Masks with perspective architectural paintings and theatrical masks.
Temple of Apollo Palatinus
Wikipedia
The first temple to Apollo within Rome's ceremonial boundaries, constructed on the Palatine Hill by Augustus (36-28 BC). According to tradition, the site was chosen after being struck by lightning, interpreted as a divine portent.
Flavian Palace
Wikipedia
Known as the Domus Flavia, this is part of the vast Palace of Domitian on the Palatine Hill. Completed in 92 AD by Emperor Titus Flavius Domitianus and attributed to his master architect Rabirius, it served as the official public wing of the imperial palace complex.
Domus Augustana
Wikipedia
The central residential part of the Palace of Domitian on the Palatine Hill, completed in 92 AD. It functioned as the private quarters of the emperor, complementing the public Domus Flavia.
Domus Transitoria
Wikipedia
Emperor Nero's first palace, damaged or destroyed by the Great Fire of Rome in 64 AD and later extended by his Domus Aurea. Fragments of its elaborate decorations in opus sectile survive in the Palatine Museum.
Palatine Museum
Wikipedia
A museum located on the Palatine Hill housing sculptures, fragments of frescoes, and archaeological material discovered on the hill. Notable holdings include portraits of Nero, Agrippina Minor, Antoninus Pius, Hadrian, and Marcus Aurelius, as well as paintings from the Domus Transitoria.

The Arch of Constantine is the largest Roman triumphal arch, dedicated by the Senate to Emperor Constantine the Great in AD 315 to commemorate his victory over Maxentius at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge in AD 312. Situated between the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill along the Via Triumphalis, it measures 21m high, 25.9m wide, and 7.4m deep with three arched bays. The arch is remarkable for its extensive use of spolia — sculptural reliefs, medallions, and statues reused from earlier monuments of Trajan, Hadrian, and Marcus Aurelius — combined with Constantinian-era carvings, creating a striking juxtaposition of artistic styles spanning over two centuries.

The life of Moses encompasses his birth in Egypt during Pharaoh's persecution of the Israelites, his adoption by Pharaoh's daughter, his flight to Midian after killing an Egyptian, and his calling at the burning bush to lead the Israelites out of slavery. God appeared to Moses in a bush that burned but was not consumed, revealing the divine name and commissioning Moses to confront Pharaoh. Through ten plagues and the parting of the Red Sea, Moses led the Exodus from Egypt. He received the Ten Commandments on Mount Sinai and guided the Israelites through forty years in the wilderness.

The Virgin Mary typically holds or sits near the body of her dead son, accompanied by other mourners such as Mary Magdalene, John the Evangelist, Joseph of Arimathea, and Nicodemus. Summary
The story of Judith and Holofernes comes from the deuterocanonical Book of Judith. When the Assyrian general Holofernes besieged the Jewish city of Bethulia, the beautiful widow Judith devised a plan to save her people. She entered the Assyrian camp, gaining Holofernes' trust with her beauty and wisdom. When Holofernes became drunk at a banquet, Judith seized his own sword and beheaded him. She returned to Bethulia with his head, and the leaderless Assyrian army fled in confusion. The story represents the triumph of virtue over tyranny and of the weak over the powerful through faith in God.

The Incredulity of Saint Thomas refers to the episode in the Gospel of John where the Apostle Thomas refused to believe that Jesus had risen from the dead until he could see and touch Christ's crucifixion wounds. This episode gave rise to the term "Doubting Thomas."
When the resurrected Jesus appeared to the disciples, Thomas was absent. He declared, "Unless I see the nail marks in his hands and put my finger where the nails were, and put my hand into his side, I will not believe." A week later, Jesus appeared again and invited Thomas to touch his wounds, leading to Thomas's declaration of faith: "My Lord and my God!"

This fundamental Christian belief holds that God exists as one being in three distinct persons. In art, the Trinity is often depicted with God the Father supporting Christ crucified, with the Holy Spirit represented as a dove between them, visualizing the unity and distinction of the three persons.

During the crucifixion, darkness covered the land for three hours, and at the moment of his death, Jesus cried out "It is finished." The temple veil was torn in two, and an earthquake occurred.
